reviewText:
Ultron: You are annoyingly nave.
Vision: Well, I was born yesterday.

Avengers: Age of Ultron goes full throttle start to finish, which also means it shouldve slowed down to let everyone catch their breath a few times.  We all know the plot, but as the devils in the details, the question is how do all the pieces fit together.  The answer is: Very well, indeed.  Even if some of them get forced into place.

Whats Good: Its a Joss Whedon vehicle.  That means the rare synergy of action, humor and drama weve come to expect from him.  Lots of cameos and appearances from supporting characters- Sam Wilson/Falcon and James Rhodes/War Machine for example- as well as other denizens of the MCU.  Even Idris Elba shows up for a minute as Heimdall (hey- thats three black guys!  Wow.).  Theres also all the references and easter eggs youll have fun spotting: like a certain African nation, for example.

For those (rightly) complaining about Hawkeyes lack of well, anything remotely useful, brace yourselves.  Clint Barton looms large in this one and is quite relevant to the plot.  Go figure.  Besides that theres quite a few twists you won't expect and things definitely get worse before they get better.  The Visions debut is a bit shaky, but works out ok.

Whats Bad: believe it or not, the movie does have some warts.  Noticeable in their absence are Pepper Potts and Jane Foster; though explained via some light comedy, you still wonder why they're not around.  One of my main bones to pick was Ultrons origin sequence; it was surprisingly brief, almost rushed- like it was only there because it had to be.  He almost literally just snaps into being and is already rolling. It really wouldnt have hurt anything to spend a little more time on Ultrons development and a lot less on the 3D-driven mindless, wholescale destruction fight scenes (and yes, I do mean the Iron Man vs Hulk battle.  That one might as well have been ripped from anime).  Because frankly, some of them didn't make much sense and kind of send you into sensory overload.  More than a few times theres simply too much going on here; you're exhausted just watching them.

And the emergence of the Maximoff twins brings us right back to the ongoing unanswered question of how the X-Men figure into all of this.  Because theres no way they can, even with Magnetos children in the mix.

Whats Left: the blockbuster youve been waiting for that sets up just about every other Marvel movie on the horizon.  Oh, and theres only one mid-credits scene to watch for- and its a killer!  Hint: its foreshadowed during the movie.  4/5 stars.

Spoiler Warning:  When Tony Stark (Robert Downey Jr.) tries to build an artificial intelligence named Ultron that would protect Earth from more alien attacks for instance. Ultron (voiced by James Spader) gets a mind "and body" of his own and Earth's protector becomes their greatest enemy.
  Despite Age of Ultron being long without a solid story. Age of Ultron is anything but a Michael Bay movie. Because it entertained me rather than just making me deaf while checking my watch like I did with Transformers: Age of Extinction.
  Ultron isn't as memorable as he could have been. Since it gets repetitive seeing many versions of him destroyed over and over again. Despite great voice work by James Spader. Vision (Paul Bettany) though is much more of a succesful addition to the film.
  My problems with the film are mostly the Hulk/Bruce Banner and Black Widow romance and taking the time to tell us Hawkeye has a family. The film slows down just to put the Avengers at Hawkeye's farm where they regroup against Ultron.
  That reminded me of how the Ninja Turtles regroup by always hiding out at farms lol. While Hawkeye having a wife and kids doesn't make you more interested in him like I guess Whedon intended.
  The Widow and Hulk romance didn't work for me since there was no hint in the first film that she can calm down the Hulk. They should have brought back Betty Ross to calm down the Hulk. Sparks fly when Widow is with Captain America...not Bruce Banner. So they should have built on her chemistry with Captain more  from Winter Soldier.
  The Avengers not knowing Agent Coulson is alive finally also bugs me. Since according to Whedon Couslon is alive on tv but still dead in the movies. Huh ? And Tony Stark is a bit too much of a jerk to care about in this one. He's too non-solant about the fact the he created Ultron who wants to destroy mankind and barely sees what the big deal is.
  Still Avengers; Age of Ultron is pretty kick ass for super hero fans. And if it was just comic nerds writing the reviews at rottentomatoes; the reviews would be 100%. The scenes with Vision especially made it easy to forget my problems with it. And yes there's some great action like Hulk vs Iron Man in his Hulk buster armor.

The story line is a basic Avengers vs. Ultron, a robot with artificial intelligence who is aided by two human experiments. This battle requires the Avengers to pull out all the stops and come together as a team. Midway through the film we get to know the Hawkeye (Jeremy Renner) family. We are also introduced to a new Avengers. The film ends with it being open to a sequel which will result in them battling an even greater force.

As always the action is long. The film develops the Hulk/Black Widow romance and Captain America uses a swear word or two. There is some humorous banter as you would expect, but not at the level it was in past films. Gwyneth Paltrow is not in the film. Look for Stan Lee. The film does answer the question "Iron Man or Hulk?"

The film asks basic questions about war, killing, and the use of violence in general but doesn't get so heavy as to weigh down the popcorn.

In only seven short years, the Marvel Cinematic Universe (MCU) has revolutionized the manner in which we enjoy movies.  The characters and their storylines are only portions of the pie, while the fluidity and continuity is what makes this rapidly growing nexus the uncontrollable mega-monster that it is today.

From the Iron Man and Captain America films to Thor and Guardians of the Galaxy, one would think these tales would eventually reach their peak  and create a spiraling domino effect that would weaken the bond between them.  After all, nothing lasts forever, right?  Well, something tells me the brain trust behind the MCU doesnt see it that way.  And, theres nothing in this latest MCU chapter, Avengers: Age of Ultron, to indicate a lack of momentum going into the future.  In fact, it appears as though Marvel is just getting started

SYNOPSIS / POTENTIAL SPOILERS
Joss Whedon (Marvels The Avengers, Serenity) returns to write and direct The Avengers: Age of Ultron, picking-up in the aftermath of Iron Man 3 and Captain America: The Winter Soldier.  The Avengers, including Iron Man (Robert Downey, Jr.), Captain America (Chris Evans), Thor (Chris Hemsworth), Hawkeye (Jeremy Renner), Black Widow (Scarlett Johansson), and The Hulk (Mark Ruffalo as Bruce Banner), are in a waning war against Hydra  cleaning-up their last remnants.

In their latest battle, the Avengers encounter two super-powered individuals, Quicksilver (Aaron Taylor-Johnson) and the Scarlet Witch (Elizabeth Olsen), and through exposure to Scatlet Witchs magic, begin experiencing their greatest fears.  Iron Mans experience leads him to create a program, with the help of Banner, to put an iron solider throughout the world  as a means to constantly serve and protect.  But, the outcome is far more diabolical in nature when it produces an artificial intelligence, called Ultron (voiced by James Spader), which believes the elimination of humanity is the best course of action for peace and prosperity.

REACTION
Whether youll ultimately deem Age of Ultron to be better than the first film will be a debate worthy of endless discussion, however, Joss Whedons script and plot points hardly produce earth shattering revelations  and is far too reminiscent of Iron Man 2 for comfort.  Naturally, the comparison between those two films stems from the villains motives  where youll find Scarlet Witch and Quicksilvers beef with Iron Man (and the Avenges, who are seemingly guilty by association) to be nearly identical to that of Ivan Vanko.

Minor plot complaints aside, which still work perfectly fine for what they achieve, will not hinder your viewing experience in the least.  With that said, Age of Ultron is not far from being considered a perfect comic book film  delving into a plethora of prudent, untapped areas that fans have been clamoring for, such as a greater emphasis on the previous films lesser utilized characters, like Hawkeye, Black Widow, and the Hulk  all of whom player significantly greater roles than they have in any other MCU installments from the past (aside from Bruce Banner, who had his own film  despite the fact that it didn't star Mark Ruffalo).

The big three also receive their fair share of screen time  and, not unlike the first film, spend a considerable amount of time verbally sparring with one another.  Thus, a clear-cut line is drawn in the sand between Iron Man and Captain America that will obviously spill over into next years Captain America: Civil War  and, believe it or not, it looks as though even Thor clearly picks his side (although he excuses himself from the fray).  Nevertheless, the main talking points will revolve around where this battle with Ultron leaves these three heavy hitters after the dust has settled.

Speaking of Ultron, its nice to see a formidable villain take the reigns in the noticeable absence of Loki and Thanos (whos does appear briefly, though).  Regardless, Ultron fits the bill of a super-villain magnificently, though  and James Spader quite simply knocks it out of the park with his voice work.  The back-and-forth exchanges between Spader and Downey, Jr. provide a unique father/son dynamic, inevitably leading the creation of The Vision (one of the films most memorable occurrences).

The Vision (voiced by Paul Bettany) is one of several new characters, along with the aforementioned Scarlet Witch and Quicksilver, to be fully integrated into the team.  Elizabeth Olsens Scarlet Witch, more so than the rest, is the most interesting (not to mention stunning) addition to the franchise, and should be a significant asset moving forward.  Quicksilver, on the other hand, is the complete opposite of his X-Men: Days of Future Past counterpart  as Aaron Taylor-Johnson spends the majority of his screen presence being underutilized and under-appreciated.

Outside of the various storylines (and there a ton to pay attention to) and character developments, the vast amount of CGI-heavy action is almost overwhelming (and visually breathtaking).  The action sequences are fun (especially the Avengers Assemble shots at the beginning and end of the film), while the lighthearted comedy is also just as entertaining, too.  In particular, the scene where everyone attempts to pick-up Thors hammer is a comic book lovers delight.  And, while theres no need to spoil it for anyone, Ill just simply say that before the film is over  someone other than Thor will, indeed, wield Mjlnir.

Additionally, there are plenty of other fun Easter eggs and random cameos that continue to tie the entire MCU tighter together than ever before.  Even though plenty of familiar faces show-up throughout the course of the film, like Nick Fury (Samuel L. Jackson) and War Machine (Don Cheadle), its hard not to be overly greedy and disappointed about the characters we don't see, such as Spider-Man, Black Panther, or Ms. Marvel.  Oh, well  continued anticipation for such occurrences are reportedly not too far off in the distance, anyway.

Overall
Avengers: Age of Ultron is everything that you could possibly hope and ask for in terms of entertainment value from a superhero team-themed sequel.  There were a few obvious areas where it could have been better, possibly more original  but as a whole, theres very little to complain about.  Still, the anticipation for Age of Ultron was nowhere near the amount of excitement generated and established by Marvels The Avengers.  That doesnt mean this latest chapter isn't as potent as its predecessor  because it surely is, yet Age of Ultron clearly had to work harder than ever to out-do the epic events leading-up to and taking place during the battle of New York (prompting another major battle that was eerily similar in scale).  In the end, Joss Whedon has constructed another well-rounded summer blockbuster that is destined to dominate and squeeze the box office for nearly $2 billion.  It also sets-up the future of the MCUs Phase III  as we look towards (and endlessly discuss) the potential events of Infinity Wars Part 1 & 2 in 2018 and 2019 (respectively).

As always, the visual aspects of the film were quite strong.  In fact, all of the technical aspects are first-rate: color/photography, CGI, sound, etc.  When you watch a Disney Marvel film, you get a top-notch show.  Obviously, this ain't a Marvel film from the 1980s or early 1990s. Ugh.

Anyway, the main weakness is the same for a lot of Marvel films: a so-so villain.  James Spader's performance is great for what he's given to do, but the motivations are a bit muddy and abrupt.  I guess it provides indirect commentary of some of our social ills, but that's about it.

However, the action is spot-on--especially when the Avengers are fighting each other: it's quick and brutal.  Not quite Civil War good, but still pretty awesome.

Our favorite Avenger's movie. A great introduction to new Avengers - Vision, Scarlet Witch, War Machine, Quicksilver, and Falcon, not to mention Hawkeye's wife and kids (Barton) and their newborn. It was also interesting to see the Avengers chill at Stark Tower for a revel party and get glimpses of their personal relationships, particularly Banner and Romanoff. At the party, watch the various Avengers attempt to lift Thor's hammer, and see how Cap was able to nudge Mjolnir and Thor's look of surprise and relief. Did Cap realize he could lift the hammer so he stopped himself out of respect for Thor, or was a nudge all he could muster? Hmmmmmmmmmmm. This film was wonderfully made. A balance of personal drama, humor, and action progressed the Marvel storyline with pure satisfaction.

Some people think this is a lesser film in comparison to other larger Marvel titles. But I think its great in its own way.

In this movie we really get to see the Avengers together in action scenes throughout the entire movie. Something that hasn't been done yet in other films. We seen them working together in creative ways which I think is really cool.

This movie also really sets the tone for so many movies to follow as it shows the fears and misgivings that will slowly break the team apart. You see Thor and Hulk going their own ways. You see Tony Stark worrying so much about protecting the world and he ignores the potential dangers. Hawkeye gets his best character arc to date.

There is so much good here for a fan to not enjoy.

It's difficult to review a film that's so typically 'blockbuster' and checks all of the boxes for a major Hollywood action movie nowadays. At the same time, though, the performances by the talented actors and actresses in the film make it all feel mostly worthwhile. 'Age of Ultron' gets sadly settled with a gigantic number of plot points that it both needs to carry on from previous movies as well as set down to establish for future releases. What it does excel at, though, are the fascinating moments where Paul Bettany, Robert Downey Jr., James Spader, and others get to reflect on why they do what what they do.

The guys at RedLetterMedia put it well when they stated that the movie came off like a gigantic double-cheeseburger from a middling restaurant. There's a lot to chew on, perhaps too much, and plenty of that is pretty cheesy, but it's worth picking up overall. I feel the same way.

Age of Ultron has a reputation for being the worst Avengers movie and one of the weakest films in the MCU. In that regard, I don't entirely disagree. The climax is bloated, Thor's vision is stupid, and there's the usual problem of Marvel villains being uninteresting. The latter most problem being an especially glaring issue in this film since this is supposed to be the 'darker, more personal' Avengers film where the heroes prove that being heroes is a good thing. Ultron has a few good lines but not quite enough character to give the climax a solid 'oomph'.

All that said, I still enjoy this film. Avengers banter is great as always and, while a little bloated, the action scenes are exciting spectacles. Plus, this film has one thing that the other Avengers movies don't (not even Infinity War), it shows us the Avengers just hanging out, being friends. Those scenes show that these characters really do care for each other beyond just 'I need their help to save the world'. It made them a lot more endearing to me.

If you are considering purchasing this movie and need a review before you buy, start with every single other move in the Marvel Cinematic Universe, if you don't automatically know you need this and any others you can get your hands/eyes on then move along and find another franchise.  This one should have hooked you long before we got this far because it is A-MAZING!

Where do I even begin?

First off, this movie is not as good as the first Avengers. If I am being honest, I wouldnt even place this in my top ten Marvel films. Its bad. Like really bad and I am so thankful Joss Whedon isn't directing anymore Marvel movies. Hes a semi-decent director but hes terrible at writing. One of the major failings of this film is how the characters are written.

Tony has become a complete and total jerk. There is nothing likeable about him and the entire movie? Its his fault. Like everything in this movie is his fault yet he tries to act as if he didn't do anything wrong. The only two characters in this film that are well written are Captain America and Thor. Everyone else? Not so much

There is also this weird romance between Bruce aka the Hulk and Black Widow. This relationship makes zero sense. Their attraction was never established. It comes right out of left field and it doesnt hold a lot of weight. The romantic moments between them? Theyre dull. There is no chemistry between Mark and Scarlett.

There is also a sub-plot about Hawkeye having a family. Again, it makes no sense, doesnt add anything to the movie and its pointless. Who cares if Hawkeye has a family?

Then there is the characters of Wanda and Pietro. Theyre okay but they still feel a bit pointless. Wanda fars a be better than Pietro, showing some good character growth but there are times where she falls flat.

This is also the film that introduces Vision and he seems like an interesting character. Again, he does suffer a bit thanks to Whedons crap writing but he manages to be entertaining and likeable.

Really, this film is just a mess. All the positive aspects of this movie do not outweigh the bad. This was the start of Marvel films taking a turn. I would probably give this film a D+.

3.5/5  Superhero movies are basically all the same; they tend to follow a well-worn formula and consequently Im not a big fan. However, although A:AoU is pretty standard superhero fare it is, as always with Whedons films, elevated by a sharp script and dashes of humour. Everything you would expect is here, including top-flight effects and a huge amount of spectacle. The performances are good, with the cast are clearly very comfortable in their roles now that theyve done it all before. The story is acceptable without being remarkable and it zips along at a good pace. Theres nothing new here but its an entertaining way to spend a couple of hours.

Another notch for Marvel Cinematic Universe Success. Avengers Age of Ultron continues to spread forth an amazing collection of actors together in a phenomenal sequel to the Avengers. Joss Whedon does a marvelous job not just once but twice.

After the Captain America 2 Winter Soldier and Agents of SHIELD Season 1 in which the offshoot Nazi Terrorist group HYDRA is still in existence, promoting terrorism into the 21st century and using SHIELD and the governments of the world to in order to rule the world. Avengers 2 Age of Ultron brings the Avengers to destroy HYDRA, but they are manipulated into creating a peace keeping initiative that blows up in their faces. Ultron, the artificial intelligence created by Tony Stark to prevent alien threats like Avengers or world threats like Captain America 2 turns on them and intends to destroy. This is more than just an action movie for the sake of action, but brings to mind the importance of fighting the good fight and the limits of power. Its nice to know more things about the Avengers as they develop in the face of their new enemies and their own demons. Its nice to know that a few years living in the 21st century that Steve Rogers still misses his dreams of a normal life, or how Natasha Romanov was trained as an assassin and robbed of a life she still wants, don't get me started on Clint Barton and of course Tony Stark's ambitions. They are friends but they have a chance to be a family and more as they fight to save the world.

All this and more is just amazing. Nice to welcome back the old but also some new faces. As well as see plenty of great action. Some people complain about some stuff. The movie isn't as fresh as there is a feeling of 'sequelitis' as there is feeling to make the movie relevant. I won't go into specifics but I do believe its a little exaggerated. Joss Whedon also has said that he wanted to do more, bring more heroes and continue to develop things well into the next couple of films. Both of course didn't happen.

Still this movie is really good and well worthy of a Blu-ray and Digital Copy.

Extremely well-done effects and compositing.  The movie should have been less action and more plot as it becomes stale after half an hour of hits, bullets, and stunts. Ultron should have had more screen time and dialogue.  It is a worthy Marvel movie and one you need to watch, it was worth the rental.  All the team is doing their best with the material and the inner jokes are fun.  I can see the Joss Whedon writing and directing pedigree come out with Firefly hints.  But that effort had more time to explore a better story.  Avengers needs to be developed in a less cramped fashion, like a mini-series with more plot and less punch.

A good sequel and the Avengers cast doesn't disappoint, Ultron is a really good villain and Spader's voice is perfect for the character.

Overall story is good and will entertain.

I know I'm in the minority here in giving this film any less than rave reviews. It took a while for me to figure out what bothered me about it. I eventually realized that since Ultron was no more than a Tony Stark surrogate replete with many character traits of his creator, the viewers are subjected to the effete sarcasm, narcissism and smugness of 2 Tony Starks - when 1 is more than enough. With his ill advised, almost demented creation of Ultron, Stark was singlehandedly responsible for everything bad that happened in this film, including the violent deaths of innocent people, yet he got little more than a stern dressing down from his fellow superheroes. And then in "Civil War" he has the gall to impose the Sokovia Accords upon his peers - when he is the reason the accords had to be drafted in the first place.
What can you say, it's Marvel (I refrained from putting the "ous" on it...)

I enjoyed this movie. It had impressive action sequences, stunning visuals, and did wonders adding layers to characters we all know and love. Ultron was also a very compelling villain, one of the better villains of the MCU.

However, the main issue here is that this movie is mainly an attempt at fan service and it is extremely obvious. Much of the movie's runtime is devoted to subplots, subplots, and more subplots. It could have benefited from more Ultron and less interpersonal team drama among the Avengers. We have an entire movie universe to cover all of that in, and we won't get Ultron again anytime soon, if ever.

Those are really my only complaints though. On the whole, I was satisfied.

This movie plays better with a casual watch in your living room than the first time in a movie theater.

Backstory: I was never much of an Avengers fan, which is why the first Avengers movie was such a revelation to me. It felt like the first true comic book movie ever made.

Sequels, historically, fare poorly against their original and I was never the biggest fan of Ultron when he was first created. Granted, that was far before all the AI machines trying to destroy the world stories that began cropping up in the 80's on, but I would have to say I preferred the storyline from Abnett/Lanning in Nova (Annihilation: Conquest). Of course, that wasn't the Avengers, so there you are.

This movie has all the characters from the first one PLUS Quicksilver PLUS Scarlet Witch PLUS Ultron PLUS...ah, you get the point. Along with all the personal reflection and sneak info (infinity stones!), it's just a bit on the chubby side.

That said, sitting through it the second time, I came to appreciate what a significant and effective linchpin the movie is to the whole Marvel Cinematic Universe. Well-crafted from that aspect.

As expected, the visual effects have been ratcheted up (along with the budget, so you get more Hulk CGI time). Iron Man continues his somewhat annoying trend of having as many Iron Man suits as I have regular ones. Beyond the usual "star factor" focus on Downey Jr., the movie really plays up its most human members, which leaves Thor as the odd man out as far as screen time (not to worry, he's already had 2 movies on his own).

If I could quibble with anything in the MCU, it's the shortcuts taken with the infinity stones. First, we take the cosmic cube and call it an infinity stone, losing the whole original Thanos arc that was so much fun and the declaration of some of the others (not identified here for those of you who haven't seen all the MCU films yet), makes it seem too convenient for the ultimate gathering of stones for Thanos and his Infinity War. Thank goodness they're at least planning to allow two films for that (it only took over the whole Marvel Comics line for several months).

Bottom line, though, it's a fun movie and much richer in a leisurely watching with your remote pause button.

BORING! I love a good action/adventure -lets save the world- movie as much as the next person (if that next person is my hubby, that is). But this was a mediocre movie at best. I am kind of tired of wealthy or good looking white guys always saving the damn day. Can we maybe have some superheroes of color, maybe even an ordinary looking person and, of course, please add some more women of color as well. Women can actually kick ass. Furthermore (and I know this is somewhat confronted in the next Avengers movie), sometimes I watch the destruction caused by these 'heroes' and I think, well great there goes that guys job or some poor working class person is going to have to clean that up. I don't know, maybe I need to write my own super hero book. Anyway, after the movie ended I made the hubbers promise to remind me how much I disliked this movie if I ever try to watch another Avengers movie again.

Avengers: Age of Ultron is the second Avengers film in the Marvel Cinematic Universe. It features Ironman, Captain America, Thor, Hulk, Black Widow, Hawkeye, and introduces Quicksilver, Scarlet Witch, and Vision. The Avengers assault the stronghold of Baron von Strucker (Thomas Kretschmann), Hydras #1 thug, in the fictional Eastern European country of Sokovia. Beyond wreaking havoc on the locals, Tony Stark (Robert Downey, Jr.) recovers a scepter containing one of the six Infinity Stones before being bewitched by Wanda Maximoff (Elizabeth Olsen) and experiencing a horrible vision. Wanda and her brother Pietro (Aaron Taylor-Johnson) are products of Struckers twisted experiments. She possesses telekinetic powers, and he has superhuman speed. Stark and Dr. Bruce Banner (Mark Ruffalo) discover that the scepter holds an alien computer and want to integrate it into Starks global peacekeeping initiative, called Ultron. But the computer hijacks J.A.R.V.I.S. and gains control of Starks Ironman suits. He emerges as Ultron (James Spader), who manipulates the worlds computers at will and is bent on destroying the Avengers.

Age of Ultron is never convincing. Ultron is not an interesting villain, visually or thematically. Hes not a fully-formed character. Hes a computer program run amok or a misguided maniac. He has only one note. And he multiplies himself, which makes him disposable and boring. Likewise, the blossoming romance between Black Widow (Scarlett Johansson) and Bruce Banner is unconvincing. He looks like her father, and there is no chemistry between them. Tony Stark plays the mad scientist to the point of being a deluded and dangerous megalomaniac, completely uncaring of the consequences, which is not good. Superheroes can be antiheroes and are usually vigilantes, but this lot is no better than the villains. The action sequences are overblown and goofy, as usual. You either like that style, or you dont. But I found the Avengers too flippant about death and destruction, as if it were supposed to be funny rather than suspenseful. I like the casting and the visual effects for Scarlet Witch and Quicksilver. We don't see much of Vision, as he comes in near the end of the story, and its not clear what he is going to be about. Age of Ultron is a lackluster effort on the whole.

I won't bother to go into detail, which may discredit my review however this is all based on personal opinion and I think if I had to choose between superhero movies I still think that Man of Steel was the first superhero movie I ever liked. Maybe the captain America movie before this was good too (I haven't seen Civil War). I would consider watching superhero movies simply because that is all Hollywood is making their focus on at the moment but this movie is an OKAY movie to watch.

I would watch the Force Awakens or Skyfall just to restore my faith in the movie industry. I look for a few things in a movie,

- It has to be immediately get my attention

- I have to care about what's going on

- I have to be surprised about the plot

- It has to be original (not done before or cheesy/cliche)

The Avengers was a seemingly rushed film which made it an OKAY FILM.....

***If you are a fan of superhero movies I do think you might enjoy it.

***If you are not a fan of superhero movies, this fan will do a good job of keeping you that way.

Just finished watching this, I believe, for the third time. There are some movies that I certainly feel you can only watch when you feel a blue moon is out. This is one of those movies. The reason?? I simply say - WOW!!
With the creation of the MCU, everything is intertwined. That's what ultimately pulls me in. Not that long ago, I finished going through season two of Agents Of Shield, which parallels with Ultron. You watch the episode where Reina predicts that metal will fall from the sky,.....and that's a direct reference to this films climax, without giving anything away.
I have seen plenty of reviews that have fans scratching their heads and tearing the film to pieces with their negative comments. We all know you can't please everyone. Hey, I'm actually one of the few people I know who enjoyed Batman & Robin, My standards aren't to criticize everything, just to take it at face value and try to enjoy the movies I choose to watch. No, I thought this was a great addition to the MCU, and I can't wait to see how the next two infinity stones appear and end up in Thanos' left handed glove. Believe it or not, I'm actually a huge fan of the Batman and when it comes to merchandise, I'm a stiffler for Batman. However I still appreciate the Marvel movies that the studio keeps plunking out.
My only complaint is that I wish I had the option to go through the special features in segments rather than it all just being lumped with the movie file

Well I am sure who ever reads this is either looking for a reason not to buy/watch this, or they're looking at this in shock that someone has a differing opinion from the majority. Either way, heres my honest review.

Nothing against the blu ray itself, its fine, mine works, no issues, just like any other blu ray really. The quality and or clarity is what you'd expect from blu ray. Sound is the best part of the movie.

Now the film.....I got it as a gift. I would never buy any of these movies, there is yet to be one Marvel Cinematic Universe movie I liked, but I will say Guardians of the Galaxy was okay. The casting choices weren't bad, which to me is one of the main problems of these movies.

I actually am some one that has actually read the comics, for real, I am not one of those people that just runs with the trends and pretends I am a fan. I didn't read all of the comics mind you, mostly because I lost interest in some of them.

Going into this movie, I thought well, how bad could it be. The first was your typical introduction super hero, so to me this was like the real first true movie of the Avengers arcs. I knew Thanos wouldn't be in it because if he was in it there would be way they could top it, which sets the tone for the movie in my eyes. Its just something to quench your thirst until Thanos.

No spoilers, so I will say the story is so average, its brutal at this point. We have been seeing Super Hero after Super Hero movie several times each year now. Its like watching a michael bay movie with all show and no go, except this movie hardly even had any show, it wasn't even the action epic youd hope it be.

One complaint I have is that the weakest, most dull "heroes" overshadow the real super heroes. The casting choices were atrocious. Scarlett Witches accent felt totally fake and I couldn't get past it. I was very aware she was acting. And once again, Captain America SUCKS. Chris Evens was an okay human torch, I could buy it. Chris Evens as Captain America, it just doesnt fit him. And that girl from How I met Your Mother??? Come on. There was nobody else you could cast? The fight/battle scenes were nothing special, nothing you haven't already seen, yet most of you still seem to throw your money at for some reason. I guess its easier to go with the trend than to stand up and say it sucks. People were dumping on the Batman vs Superman movie for the same reasons they loved this movie. I don't get it.

I wanted to give this movie 2 stars, because if I was to rate it out of ten I would give it like a 3.5. However, this movie could not hold my attention enough to even keep me awake. I fell asleep watching it and I wasn't even tired. Everything about this movie just screams below average. These movies don't feel like movies, they feel like long episodes of a TV show. A Netflix exclusive, but that would be an insult to Netflix exclusives because at least they put some effort into those shows, instead of just throwing stuntmen and good looking actors and actresses in front of a green screen with a colossal budget and calling it a super hero movie.

I cant wait for this super hero fad to end, then all the casual viewers can go ruin some other franchise and the directors can actually put effort into movies and take risks. But I guess I am in the minority here, the star ratings show that. Shame!

Strong charactera, acting, story line, along with the action and drama makes this one of my favorite movies. The poetry approach from the villain is amazing as well. Hits 5 stars for me in all aspects.

I love this movie, and my heart wants me to give it at least a near perfect review. Scenes like the opening, group lunge are absolutely thrilling, and that's only one example. There are four problems for me concerning this movie, one relatively small and two ridiculously big editing mistakes. First, the small problem: just like in the debut Avengers film, Iron Man (due to overwhelming popularity) is portrayed as far more powerful than in the comics. In the first movie the example was his fight with Thor, just go flip through the JMS run of Mighty Thor to see how the Thunder God handles Stark...leaving him a grounded, mangled puppy whining about needing a ride. In AOU, Stark suckerpunches the Hulk and knocks him out. Sorry folks, a full powered Hulk ain't EVER going down that easy, even against a pissed of Sentry. Banner stuck a gun in his mouth, fired it, and the Hulk spit it out. Think on that. The scene is however, very entertaining...it's just the way it ENDED that bugs me.

Two big problems I have with AOU: one, why didn't Scarlet Witch press her advantage against Cap early in the movie (in a scene that obviously needed to be cut), Steve went ahead and knocked the hell out of Strucker anyway, useless scene there; two, due to some horrifically bad editing (once again), we're left with myriad questions regarding Thor and the ultimately befuddling pool scene.

AOU is a movie that kind of screwed the fans over by not releasing an extended cut that might have helped tie up some glaringly obvious loose ends. Forgetting that, if you love superhero movies (especially if you're into Marvel), it's an essential watch. Might help to ignore this review lol!

While The Avengers: Age of Ultron does push the bounds of credulity--Pinocchio-singing AI aside--it's an enjoyable two hours of film with enough plot to hold together the superhero team and some moments of surprising emotional depth. It's not the best Marvel has made, but it's definitely a fun ride.

Unenviable was the task ahead of Joss Whedon when it came down to make Avengers Age of Ultron. How could he hope to top or even match the success of the first Avengers film? Expectations are ridiculously high for the second movie, but thats what happens when the first one grosses almost two billion dollars and becomes the template in which everyone aspires to duplicate.

Have no fear, Whedon is here, as the mastermind and architect (along with Kevin Feige) behind the Marvel Cinematic Universe was more than up to the task. This time, Whedon not only had to juggle six protagonists, but introduce four new characters, while also servicing two additional and four huge cameos.

Whereas the previous sequels in the MCU could focus on just the story and allow the films to be more than a superhero film (i.e., Iron Man 3 buddy cop, Winter Soldier, political thriller) Age of Ultron needs to be more. It needs to continue to be the thread in which the overall narrative of the MCU continues to weave.

With all of that in mind, Whedon had a mighty task in making it all work, and honestly, work it does. At one point on screen, there were 12 heroes being heroic at the same time; twelve. Most films have issues juggling one character, let alone several.

Opening up much like Star Trek Into Darkness does, the audience is able to see the Avengers acting like a well oiled machine, with code word contingencies and the ability to calm one of its members when no longer needed. Its a terrific moment for fans, and is just the first of many over the quickly-paced two-hour, twenty-six minute ride.

The greatest compliment this long time fan can give the film, is that Whedon once again breathed life into the characters we grew up reading over the past fifty-plus years. To see the Scarlet Witch, Quicksilver and Vision on screen as Avengers, to see characters from the other films (War Machine, Falcon) remind viewers that this is not just one film in the ever-expanding universe, but the next chapter, was truly breathtaking.

Whedon never forgets what the Avengers are about, and that is the key to the success. When Ultrons final plan comes to fruition, the team is tasked with several different objectives, the least of which is saving the civilian population. This comes right off the pages of the Avengers comic with Cap leading the way and giving directives. It is a contrast to some of the hero destruction porn moviegoers sometimes witness and is not a criticism of those films, but rather an example that the Avengers are always about being more than what is expected.

Ultron by the way, voiced by James Spader, was a terrific foil and protagonist, twisting the teams overall mission of peace, while also staying true to the characters origins from the pages of the Avengers. There is not a lot of time with all the ingredients that Whedon must throw into this recipe to service everything possible, but he does a wonderful job of bringing Ultron to life, with all the Daddy issues the character had in the comics.

Considering all those elements, Whedon also gives terrific character moments to the entire team, which is impressive when considering how many members are on the squad.

Marvel will continue its hot streak at the box office with Age of Ultron. Fans will attempt to compare it to the other films previously released or use superlatives as best Marvel film ever. In the end, it will take its rightful place in the canon and does not need to be compared to any of the universes other movies - its the Avengers.

This movie has the coolest shots ever. It has one of the best casts with every single actor having chemistry with anyone they're with and it's awesome. I love the motivation, there's no more SHIELD as far as they're concerned and no *one* big brother entity is egging them on to save the world (unless you're that nerd who likes to watch every bit of MCU I do suggest AoS). Cool beans. What I don't understand is why would they have Natasha in charge of calming down the Hulk. As I recall Cap was barely able to give Hulk an order he liked in Avengers. Tony kept on pushing buttons in hopes that Bruce would hulk out in front of him and then got excited when it happened. Thor was another part I had a problem with. Explaining away the sokovia debris was lacking. I don't know, I kept losing track of things but I was down with it for the most part.

I'm a big Marvel comic book movie fan, so I've seen all of them in theaters, often in 3D IMAX. Age of Ultron, like the other Avengers and Captain America movies, was a real spectacle with dramatic fight scenes, lots of special effects, kick ass science fiction gadgets and white-hat black-hat action. Still, I bought the DVD for Age of Ultron after watching Civil Wars, its sequel, because I watch for the plot and character development. That was always Marvel's strength, and it is what makes the movies worth watching at all. While each movie can stand alone, re-watching Age of Ultron added a lot to my appreciation of Civil Wars. There was surprisingly little wasted action, as themes and story were developed with an eye on the continuing story.

Let's face it. Nowadays anyone can produce a real spectacle of a movie. Need 10,000 orcs battling flying monkeys on a moon of Jupiter? Hire a few of the hundreds of guys in the SFX part of the credits, and you'll have all the orcs, monkeys and Jovian moons you want. Age of Ultron, however, has some great characters and good ensemble acting. The fantasy sequences were nicely done and true to character, but it was scenes of casual banter that pulled everything together. Given that the protagonists are basically unbelievable, they were pretty believable, and where unbelievable, they were a lot of fun.

FORMAT: Blu-Ray UPC: 7-86936-84671-3 RELEASED: 2015-10-02 TITLE: Avengers: Age of Ultron (2015) PG-13 2:21:19 Scarlett Johansson, Robert Downey Jr., Chris Evans, Samuel L. Jackson Joss Whedon (Director) Joss Whedon does it again: If you liked the first Avengers movie, then you will probably like this one. The plot in a nutshell: Bad Guys, AGAIN, do bad things (on a large scale); Good Guys (and Gals), yet AGAIN, try to stop said Bad Guys and, AGAIN, fun (mostly) ensues! See the other reviews on this page for more detail and/or other opinions regarding the plot of the movie. VIDEO: 2.39:1 Color 1080p MPEG-4 AVC (29.9 Mbps) The movie's image is reasonably sharp (without any obvious edge-enhancement), has very good contrast and has decent shadow detail (as seen in the dark and shadowy areas, such as in the dark scenes located in the Hydra Research Base at the beginning of the movie). Also, fine detail is frequently (though not always) evident in the brighter scenes and in many close-ups. Lastly, there are no obvious artifacts such as banding, specks, white dots, hair-lines or color fluctuations. Overall, this movie's presentation on blu-ray has very good picture quality, and should satisfy the vast majority of viewers. AUDIO: DTS-HD Master Audio 7.1 The sound quality of the DTS-HD Master Audio 7.1 soundtrack for this disc, while very good, is NOT amongst the best examples of the art. Although dialog is clear and well placed, and the rear and side channels are somewhat active and fairly directional; It still never gave me that deeply moving 'you-are-there' feeling that I frequently get when listening to movies with reference-quality soundtracks (e.g.John Wick,Pacific Rim,X-men: Days Of Future Past). Don't get me wrong: this soundtrack is very good, but it definitely could have been better! EXTRAS: Director's commentary Several 'Making Of' videos Several Deleted and Extended Scenes Gag Reel None of the extras were reviewed.

I liked comic books as a kid, though in those days I was more a DC fan than a Marvel groupie.
The reason was simple: DC comic book heroes were pretty straightforward characters. They may have had some issues (Batman's origin story left him flawed in many ways) but they generally did not have any doubts about who they were and what they were about. Marvel heroes, on the other hand, seemed to be so much more angst ridden and their lives overly complicated. Puberty was hard enough, I just didn't think I needed to stagger home from another day of school and then read about how difficult life is even if you have superpowers.
Fifty years later I get it: Life is difficult. It is full of angst, drama, divorce, disappointment, war, disease and, as a result, I've become a Marvel movie fan.
Given that different - and hard won - perspective, I enjoyed "Age of Ultron" on many levels.
For example: I liked the overall premise, that brilliant people often create technologies that outstrip our ability to control them. The men who developed the internal combustion engine and then put it on wheeled vehicles probably did not realize that their inventions would one day foul the air to the point that planetary extinction is a possibility. They likely did not think that those engines, once refined, could be used to power fearsome war machines; tanks and mobile artillery pieces that would wreak havoc across much of Europe and Asia throughout the 20th Century.
Another example: There are many of us - including Stephen Hawking - who worry about the threats posed by Artificial Intelligence for the same reason. Hawking famously noted some years ago that, in the beginning, the question will be "who controls AI" but in the end that will change to "can AI be controlled?"
The jury is still out on that one.
I also liked the fact that this movie humanized some of the characters: Hawkeye has a family, for example; Black Widow is crushing on Bruce Banner; and Tony Stark will go to almost any length to "make things right" as a result of his guilt for once being a developer of hugely powerful weapons.
This movie has been reviewed - literally - thousands of times so I won't spend a lot of time rehashing its pros and cons. Instead, I'll simply say that I enjoyed it as both a visual treat and as a movie that raised some interesting ethical and moral questions for its audience to consider.
Can't ask for much more than that.

Avengers Age of Ultron (AOU) is a very fun popcorn movie. Not nearly as good as the first Avengers but it has some very good moments. As with all Marvel movies, there is a lot of humor (sometimes too much) mixed in with the action.

Ultron, as played by James Spader, is different than what you'd expect from the comics. At times, I loved the version.  Other times, the menace that should be Ultron, was lost in trying to give him too much personality...quirky personality, to boot.

My main problem with the movie was that it ended like so many other Marvel movies, even the original Avengers. The heroes fight an almost endless onslaught of robots (Avengers: aliens; Iron man 2: Iron Man suits; Captain America: nazis). It gets to be a little too much in my opinion.

I definitely recommend the movie though, with the highlights being Vision; Hawkeye actually having an interesting storyline and excellent dialogue; Quicksilver; Hulkbuster Iron Man vs. Hulk; and the party scene where the various Avengers mix it up socially.

Marvel has the grand ability of making me not care about a single character they have in their movies. For example: I don't care about Hawkeye and his house projects. I don't care about Blackwidow and her sudden obsession with Hulk's great green tallywhacker. I don't care about Quicksilver or Scarlet Witch (both of whose histories were barely even talked about so I had no idea who they were until someone told me), and I don't care about Hulk's edginess to live away from society. Speaking of Hulk, can he or can't he control his powers? Both Avengers movies are extremely unclear on this.

As far as the movie goes, the visuals are cool but the more you watch it the more fake it looks (yet Lord of the Rings animated parts still look more convincing after all these years). Ultron is kinda cool, but even for Superhero movies the whole "humans are bad, must destroy for clean slate" story is becoming tiresome.

I hoped I could send this to my short list of Marvel movies I actually like (currently only populated by Winter Soldier and Guardians of the Galaxy), but so far it falls beneath the first Avengers and sits happily above the worst Marvel movie.. Iron Man 2.

For fans of Marvel Comics Avengers, I'm pretty sure this will please.  For those who haven't been exposed to Marvel Universe and Marvel's Avengers this is certainly a good place in which to start.

The one thing I have truly been impressed with is the casting.  I would be hard pressed to have been at a discussion table to decide who should play any given character.  Robert Downey Jr. certainly pulls off the Tony Stark arrogance with aplomb.  The two Chris's wear their respective wardrobes as if they were born to them.  Mark G. does his best Bruce Banner yet.

The introduction of three new characters in addition to Ultron made for a nice change as well as good addition to the Avengers ensemble.  All in all, this was a well balanced movie, long, but not so long as to detract, loaded with great action, superb effects and a couple very nice subplots.

However this is definitely not a perfect film either. Definitely a fun and enjoyable movie though.

Age of Ultron was average.  Not great, not very in-depth, but ok.  That being said, I have several significant issues with this movie.

Steve's off-hand comment about "language" was very dumb, as he was a soldier during WW2 and he was surrounded by guys who cussed.  It would actually be more surprising, and in character, if in that scene he swore and the other characters were shocked because they didn't expect that from "Captain America".  Just sayin'.  Probably would've made a better running joke too.

Also, AOU brought an out-of-the-blue romance between Natasha and Dr. Banner that felt painfully forced.  I had to hold down my bile every time they had a remotely mushy scene together.  I just couldn't take it seriously at ALL, especially when the previous Avengers film had heavily indicated some sort of relationship between Nat and Clint.

Thor's side-quest to the pool where he did some sort of crazy drug trip to get a vision from the Norns or whatever, was weird and I never could understand what the point was.  I mean, I guess it was part of the plot to create Vision as well as set the stage for Thor 3, but it was justdumb.  (I hope Thor 3 isn't as stupid as Thor 2).

The only Avengers who did not feel OOC were Tony and Clint.  Despite the fact that I am a Clintasha fan, I was completely on board with Clint having a secret family.  It was incredibly cute, and rounded out his character very well.  The fatherly, caring side of him was very evident in this film, especially when he took Wanda under his wing, and then used his own body to shield that Sokovian child from being shot by Ultron.  And then there was Tony, who's guilt and fears in Age of Ultron lead directly into his actions and decisions in Civil War.

I haven't gone into the plot of AOU, but that's only because it was so flat.  I'm only going to say that the Ultron plot in the Earth's Mightiest Heroes cartoon was better than the one in this multi-million dollar movie.

Why on earth do people/critics think this was a good movie? Don't get me wrong I'm in love with the Disney/Marvel franchise but this was very disappointing. First off, I fell asleep TWICE for about 15 min through out the movie. Had my friend not nudged a couple times, I would of probably slept the entire way through. Secondly, there was waaaay too many parts in the movie that dragged so bad. There was very unnecessary dialogue and about 50% of the humor was corny as hell. Lastly, the central villain Ultron was literally the ONLY character that had me intrigued in this film. Everybody else was just... there. The Vision was alright but they could of made him a lot more interesting. 2/5 Stars and I really want to give it 3 but I just can't.

P.S. Disney's version of Quicksilver was ASS. If only they could of have Evan Peters do this part HIS way then maybe I would give it an extra star..... maybe.

AVENGERS
AGE OF ULTRON

The first Avengers film was one of the best films to ever be put out by the Marvel universe, or the MCU for its films and such. By far one of the most fun films to ever hit theaters the expectations for the follow up film was high indeed. Like most sequels try to do this film was a bigger flick taking the action from the first and turning it up making it feel even more epic. Still I am not sure if it is the better film between the two.

Years have passed since the events of the first film in which New York was destroyed. Now The Avengers have moved on to fighting against HYDRA and the like and upon doing so in a recent mission the stumble upon a stone that was in Lokis scepter. Tony Stark and Bruce Banner once back in New York try to harness its power to finalize Starks Ultron Global Defense system. Unfortunately they were very successful and the system takes on a life of its own even eliminating Starks Jarvis system. Now Ultron has taken it upon himself to end humanity in order to save the planet. It will now take not only the Avengers we know but a few new comers to try and save the world from its own would be savior.

This was an action packed film that is defiantly a worthy follow up to the first Avengers film. Like I said before the action has been blown up and made the film feel more epic than its predecessor. It also gets a little more personal for the characters involved making them look into themselves and their worth. But with that I think a little of the fun of the first film has been taken out. Now by that I don't mean the overall fun of a summer blockbuster and the action that goes with it, I mean the humor and comedic moments of the first are not as present in this one as compared to the first. Those moments are still to be found here but not as much and those were my favorite things about the first film.

Of course the cast is amazing here as one would expect, everyone from our heroes to the villains to the small roles. Also returning writer/director Josh Whedon did a great job upping the ante for his second Avengers flick. I hope he returns to the MCU at some point. The Blu-Ray comes with some great behind the scenes and making of features as well as the deleted scenes and gag reel. Of course though it is the commentary from Whedon that I enjoy the most, love the commentaries. This is a highly recommended film from me that is one of the best in the MCU.

If I could give this 4 1/2 outta five I would.  Age of Ultron has alot of great things in it. While played great by Spader, Ultron was just too human.  His plan, his motives, his ticks,  all too human.  Ultron is suppose to be cold, calculating, and heartless.  How he acts especially towards the end just isn't who ultron really is.

But all in all, still a nearly perfect Marvel movie second only to the Captain America and first Avengers movies.

When I first saw Ultron I said, "That's Phineas T. Ratchet, the evil robot in "Robots" who took over Mr. Bigweld's company and came up with the phrase "Why be you when you can be new?" Ultron looked and sounded and acted exactly like him, and from that point on I was unable to take the movie seriously. There were some major problems as well. This super intelligent robot who came from where exactly? The movie wasn't too clear on that. Was it Loki's scepter, or something else, and if it was Loki's scepter, how did he get his hands on it, and how was he able to use it on the woman to control her into making his new body when he supposedly was the scepter as well? And why didn't he use the scepter on anyone else to control them? And if he was this super powerful super intelligent robot why was he always making so many stupid mistakes and his dialogue was like the corney dialogue of some "Hey dude" kid in middle school.  Over all a big disappointment

The good guys win again..... How terribly boring. Stan Lee needs to learn how to create a villain. Every avengers movie always has the good guys prevailing and it is an obvious victory. Where is the avengers movie where the victory is a hollow victory? Like Nolan's second Batman movie the Dark Knight. Batman won in the end, but only kinda. In fact, if you really pay attention it is clear that the Joker won. Several of the Harry Potter movies has evil wining at the end of the movie and so does Star Wars (especially episodes 3 and 5)... But, not the avengers. Tell me, what is the point of watching a movie where the end is as predictable as me hitting the snooze button when my alarm first goes off in the morning? Great actors. Good acting. Now, the most popular action movies are the ones based on comic book characters. After several decent films, Marvel Studios reputation skyrocketed. This movie's reputation, along with Marvel Studios, have become overinflated. The movie was not terrible by any means. It had three major problems.

One is that it felt similar to the first films, from the fights to the themes. After watching it a handful of times, you can see the movie share multiple traits of the first movie in the series. For instance, one of the characters go on a rampage which requires another to fight against him. The main difference is that there are more special effects and it look better than the last one. It only introduced one new idea, which was not discussed. The fact there are multiple characters outside the group with abilities was easily dismissed after a brief conversation in the beginning.

The second problem was the introduction of a large cast of characters. As a fan and comic book collected, it was awesome seeing people I recognize. Unfortunately, those characters had an insignificant amount of screen time. Over half the characters which were added were killed. After adding new characters that will appear in future films, it appears the Avengers film will only focus on the same group of characters. It is not a bad idea. It is just dull after seeing multiple films with all the other character which viewers more than likely understand.

At last, the film's story was lacking. The story was like a basic action movie: stop the bad guy at the big final fight. The path to get there was interesting. Throughout, the movie the viewers were teased of an ultimate plot which expands to all the Avengers films. The epic plot vastly overshadowed the film's story and made it uninteresting. It is hard for fans to see the film is holding back in order to push more films out. In other words, a significant portion of this movie was a waste of time. You really should be watching the next films to get a good story.

Overall, the movie felt like a traditional action movie with Marvel branding. Marvel has made great (and better) stories in films, comics, and television series. If characters with an important standing in the film (and especially other Marvel films and TV series), do not kill them of before focusing on them somewhat. The film was overrated because of its predecessor and characters that were included.

Seriously one of the best movies marvel has put out yet. A darker movie as it delves into the psyche and shows the heroes we know and love in darker places while hinting at a future even worse. Age of Ultron is a movie that gets hate for weird reasons, some hate on it for being too jokey in the movie meanwhile its trying to show its otherwise stagnant heroes in a much deeper and darker light(heh). You can seriously see the tinges of paranoia Tony Stark holds deep within him as he creates a robot out of a dangerous weapon to save the world before its needed to be saved so that it does not need to be "Avenged". Captain America continues to struggle with him being a general fish out of water and reminisces on a past he never got a happiness he never got that he wishes for dearly. Black Widows dark past as an Assassin is shown to a certain degree, Bruce Banner finds out the consequences of being the Hulk the hard way and Thor has visions of a future Apocalypse coming to his people that say is his fault. Age of Ultron is dark much darker than most of its other movies before it aside from "The Winter Soldier" its a movie with heart and soul that really wants to just tell you about its characters because these are characters we've seen for already 9 years and the series until now never showed just how disturbed these characters are. Age of Ultron is a success as it has a brilliant story, sheds light more on these well known characters, delivers us a great villain in the form of a Young Ultron (with a wonderful performance by James Spader), gives us some really cool fights,  and successfully hints at the future of the series as it goes into its next phase where many wars will commence.

3 Stars. (Spoiler Alert!) I recently rewatched the Avengers [Iron Man (Robert Downey Jr.), Thor (Chris Hemsworth), Captain America (Chris Evans), Hulk (Chris Evans), Black Widow (Scarlett Johansson), Hawkeye (Jeremy Renner), and Nick Fury (Samuel L. Jackson)] assemble for 2015's summer blockbuster hit. This time Tony Stark (aka Iron Man) and Bruce Banner (aka Hulk) create an artificial intelligence from Lokis staff, which was lost after the first Avengers movie. The AI, name Ultron, was given one goal - to provide peace on Earth. He goes power hungry and decides the fastest method is to annihilate the human race and rebuild. He has also taken it upon himself rip the Avengers team apart from within, setting the stage for the next Marvel movie, Captain America: Civil War (2016). Once again we are provided with lots of fast paced action that often gets jumbled and lost. It tests the limits of reality even in this superhero world, filling it with a number plot holes and problems that makes it more mindless. Weldon does a decent job to please fans of the Marvel Universe and tame the over zealous script. He spends some time on character development, with showing Hawkeyes family and the blossoming relationship between Banner and Black Window. In the end its just another chapter in Avengers timeline as we wait for the next installments. The second viewing at home was better than spending 2.5 hours in the theater, but perhaps that was helped along by a few beers.

I thought that the Marvel Cinematic Universe movie, "The Avengers: Age  of Ultron is with regard to the over-all development of Marvel's supposed aim of "creating a platform from which to tell these kinds of stories" a perfect continuation of the unfolding of the Avengers' story. The one criticism I have of the film however is a major one and it goes to the reported apparent penchant for Joss Whedon to "kill" a major character in his productions. In my opinion the death of mutant Quicksilver was the second biggest mistake made in the development of the MCU.  it is on the caliber of not including Hank Pym and Janet Van Dyne as founding members of the Avengers.  Kevin Feige can say he doesn't have to adhere to the history of Marvel if he wants but simply because he says it does not make it true.

I find it extremely distasteful and unfortunate that Quicksilver was killed at all let alone so quickly over what probably amounts to some wha for us as fans is some pure bulls*** "professional" crap of the "rights debate/discussion" with Fox and the whole mutant/enhanced controversy.  In my view Marvel simply didn't have to say where Wanda and Pietro came from.  In the comics as I remember it was a while before we learned  they were actually Magneto's children, it could have been (and actually still can be the same thing).

Except of the major mistake the movie was and excellent continuation of the Avengers story. (please forgive any grammatical and/or punctuation errors since I tried to correct them but the feed won't allow me to).

I enjoy the Avengers movies -- they're not my favorite films of all time nor are they cinematic masterpieces, but they're enjoyable brain candy nonetheless.  I go to an Avengers film expecting to have a good time, to enjoy rip-roaring action and likable superheroes and memorable (or at least tolerable) villains.  And for me, the first "Avengers" film was a great movie, fun and exciting with just the right amount of humor to level things out.  As later films starring the individual members of the Avengers have gotten darker, their stories intertwining more and more, I've wondered just where the franchise is going with all this, and I went into "Age of Ultron" with some trepidation but still hoping to enjoy myself.

While I had fun with this movie, it's still not without some big flaws.  And while I enjoyed what I saw and will probably watch it again, this movie is a dire sign that the Marvel Cinematic Universe is starting to grow too unwieldy, and runs a real risk of collapsing under its own weight if it's not careful.

As the Avengers continue in their quest to keep the peace around the world, Tony Stark, the man behind Ironman's mask, decides that their efforts are not enough, and opts to create the ultimate peacekeeping machine -- Ultron, an intelligent mechanical life form that will do what the Avengers cannot.  His plan backfires, and Ultron decides that the only way to ensure peace is to eliminate the Avengers themselves.  As Ultron finds allies in two super-powered orphans -- Quicksilver and Scarlet Witch, who blame Stark for the deaths of their parents -- and the Avengers scramble to confront this new menace, the team is forced to confront the tragedies of their pasts... and a terrible threat brewing in the future.  Egos clash, dark secrets are revealed, and in the end unlikely alliances must be made to keep Ultron from setting a plan into motion that could wipe out humankind for good...

As always for an Avengers movie, the special effects are top-notch, immersing us in the world and giving us plenty of "technology porn" to gape at.  The movie strikes a good balance between the slick, stylized look of a comic book and the grittiness of the real world -- it never gets too campy or colorful for its own good, yet maintains a sense of fun and doesn't forget that, for all its epicness, it's still a comic book movie at heart.  And while the fight scenes can get pretty busy, they're never too complex to tell who's fighting who (a big failing of the "Transformers" movies).

The movie manages to keep a light touch as well.  The Avengers may argue and butt heads, but their personalities bounce well off each other, and they're still able to joke and tease one another like the old friends and colleagues they are.  It's difficult to get too invested in the new characters, however -- Quicksilver, Scarlet Witch, and Vision -- as they're too thinly characterized to make much of an impression.  By far the best new character is Ultron, who comes across as "Tony Stark's dark side" at times -- snarky and brilliant, but ruthless and seeing individuals as tools to be used and discarded.  I just wish we could have seen more of him.

All that said, however, the movie's greatest flaw is that it just tries to do way too much in one go.  It's nearly impossible to give every single Avenger their own story arc, but this movie sure tries to do so.  So many subplots are juggled that it feels like the movie gets cluttered, and while it was nice to see some characters (like Hawkeye and Black Widow) get more depth, it's still difficult to follow so many storylines in one go.  Either some of the subplots needed cut out and given their own movie, or "Age of Ultron" needed to be a two-parter.  Hey, if it works for "Harry Potter," "Breaking Dawn," "Mockingjay," and "Kill Bill," it could work for an Avengers movie.

A relative pointed out to me another flaw regarding this movie, and I can see her point -- namely, that this movie expects you to have seen every other Avengers movie before going into it.  Sadly, there are a few gaps in my viewing of the Avengers films (I still haven't seen "Ironman 3," and I only saw bits and pieces of "Captain America: Winter Soldier"), so I'm sure I'm missing some vital bits and pieces.  And for people who are only casual fans of the Avengers, who have only seen a few of the movies or only watch the major ensemble Avengers movies, they're probably going to go into this movie lost and confused, as it makes a LOT of references to past Avengers movies.  Heck, this movie even makes callbacks to "Guardians of the Galaxy," which isn't even an Avengers film...

As the movies get more convoluted, twining plots and building on each other, they run the risk of losing people who don't follow the films religiously.  I'm not saying a film franchise can't build a mythos and a continuity, but I do think that the movies should be able to stand alone as well, especially the huge ensemble ones.  Just my opinion, however.

Definitely not perfect, and definitely not as good as the first "Avengers" movie, "Age of Ultron" is still fun to watch, albeit a very busy and complicated film that can be confusing if there are holes in your viewing of the previous Avengers films.  This film also seems to be laying the groundwork for future Marvel films, such as "Civil War" and "Thor: Ragnarok," so it's obvious Marvel and Disney are nowhere near done yet...

Nine Things about the Movie "Avengers: Age of Ultron"

[If you haven't seen this movie yet, there are spoilers.
And a caveat: I have never read the comics, so I have no opinion on how the movie compares to the comics. My thoughts are on this movie only.]

1. By now, The Avengers (and their technology) are so overpowered that they're basically just magical. They need to stop being superheroes and just go teach at Hogwarts.

2. The character of Ultron is a complete mess. He's an alien AI that wakes up, absorbs the internet, and then thinks he's God (but not only God - he's specifically the Christian God). After soaking in all human knowledge, he looks around, and thinks that the most logical way to bring peace to earth is to kill everybody. But he also gets scared and mad and has temper tantrums like a kindergartener.

Oh, and he looks like a rejected design for The Terminator.

3. While we're on the topic of Ultron, I have to point out that the idea of an AI that tries to become God has been used for decades. It goes back at least to the 1984 classic novel Neuromancer, which changed science fiction forever. Even Johnny Depp's AI in 2014's Transcendence was better than this lame metal ego. And when Vision stops him by grabbing his head and basically taking away his wi-fi connection, you know you have a bad villain.

I think Ultron's name should be changed to Leastron.

But I do like Samuel L. Jackson's nickname for him, "the platinum bastard."

4. The movie tries to be deep, but if you listen to what's said, it's just funny. Ultron says that we create what we dread: men of peace create engines of war, and parents create children. I was so caught off-guard by the apparent dreadfulness of parenthood that I didn't wonder until later, if men of peace create engines of war, do men of war create engines of peace? Is that what Ultron was getting at?

Later, Vision says stuff like "things aren't beautiful because they last" and "humans think order and chaos are opposites" and other pseudo-Buddhist quotes that are only impressive if you're a stoned 15-year-old.

5. When Hulk smashes a city, and the whole world is looking for the Hulk for possible arrest, the Avengers decide to avoid any consequences and go into hiding. And out of all the places on Earth they could hide from danger, Hawkeye takes them to meet his wife and kids. So Hawkeye's wife can lecture him by saying that she supports his "avenging" but... she's pregnant and family is important too.

6. The movie is sexist. One theme of the movie is the "deep" question of what could turn a human into a monster. Black Widow thinks she might be a monster because she can't have kids.

And while all the men are wearing suits that cover their skin up to their neck, nobody mentions to either of the two women in the movie that their suits were always zipped down enough to show their cleavage.

Oh, and their names are Black Widow - who wears a dominatrix outfit - and Scarlet Witch - who takes care of the schoolgirl fetish. A spider that kills males after sex and a cute but bloody witch. People at Marvel have obvious issues with females.

7. The only way you get any "deep" character development is when they have visions about their past or future, caused by a spiteful Russian lady. And then Thor visits a cave to talk to the water spirits, to get another vision.

8. Ultron could have destroyed the earth by, say, covering the earth in chemical weapons, or swarms of nanobots, or lots of other things that would have overwhelmed the Avengers and prevented them saving the Earth. But Ultron, in his infinite wisdom, decides to lift a city up in the air, and then drop it. You know, so the Avengers can all get together in one place and stop him.

At about this time in the movie, Hawkeye tells another character, "The city is flying. We're fighting an army of robots. I have a bow and arrow. None of this makes sense." I bet that was going to be the original title of the movie, but it was too long.

9. I get that this is a superhero movie, and it's not supposed to be deep or meaningful. But this is ridiculous.
In its favor, this movie is interesting visually. If that's all you need from a movie, then this movie is great.

The pacing is a little strange on this one, not as smooth a ride or as clear a story as the previous one. The characters - even the main cast, but especially the new additions and villain - don't get nearly developed enough.

Still, the (semi) focus on hawkeye works extremely well and a I think a different cut or presentation would have made this amazing. Instead it was just fun and a good ride with some great action scenes mixed in.

The transition to the 'Next Avengers' was a little strange - I get why they did it and where they're going but it felt tacked on at the end. Knowing that the story and character choices aren't about being true to the characters, but rather more about behind the scenes decisions and contracts and deals between studios makes it feel ... off.

Still, I'm enjoying the ride, and if Ironman in his Hulkbuster suit going up against the Hulk seemed to happen very quickly and then not get talked about again... well, it was still an awesome scene. The whole movie was that way.

Age of Ultron is a confused mess of a movie that follows the troubled group of heroes as they struggle with each other to overcome Tony Stark's ill-advised decision to activate robot supermegapeacekeeper Ultron, who has concluded that he (it?) is the next step in human evolution and decides (surprise!) to rid the universe of his inferiors (i.e., the entire human race).

With the addition of Quicksilver and Scarlet Witch -- the least interesting "super" heroes since Hawkeye -- the gang must learn the deep message that only by working together can they defeat Mr. Tron. Haven't we been here before?

Can Black Widow tame enough of the Hulk to make him safe for humanity (and romance)?  Does wasting screen time with Hawkeye's wife and children make him a worthier Avenger?  Does anyone really care about the demise of Quicksilver in his first screen outing?  Is it possible not to giggle at James Spader's arch reading as the voice of Mr. Tron?  Is it really necessary to try and stitch this patchwork quilt of special excess -- 'er, effects -- into the Guardians of the Galaxy universe with another Infinity Stone subplot?  And how does that darn 'ol stone get jammed into the forehead of Paul Bettany, anyway?

Age of Bulltron is just another heifer in Marvel's Cash Cow of a series that gets weaker with each new outing.  Save your hard-earned dollars and watch it on late-nite reruns.

Avengers: The Age of Ultron is the sequel to the fourth highest grossing movie of all time. At the risk of over-hyping it any more, I can say it's probably the best Marvel movie to date. It manages to be action-packed, dramatic and even very funny in all the right places.
After the Avengers lead a successful raid against a Hydra outpost, Tony Stark (Robert Downey Jr) revives his secret peacekeeping program Ultron (voiced by James Spader) to help safeguard the planet from evil. However, Ultron interprets the idea of keeping Earth safe as a need to eradicate humankind from existence. Ultron shortly escapes from Stark's laboratory to act out its mission and it's up to the Avengers, along with their new allies, the twins Quicksilver (Aaron Taylor-Johnson) and Scarlet Witch (Elizabeth Olsen) to stop Ultron from carrying out this genocidal act.
Even though it is darker than the first film, Avengers: The Age of Ultron is still able to capture the charm and humour from its main characters that we have grown to love over the years. Tony Stark is still as witty as ever, delivering his trademark hilarious one-liners and Hawkeye's (Jeremy Renner) scenes have some of the most poignant moments in any Marvel film. But perhaps the biggest surprise were the twins Quicksilver and Scarlet Witch, who played a much more important role than I thought they would. There's rarely a dull moment.
