Just as good as the first one if you remove the rose colored glasses we all wore when viewing the original. Both are flawed, but I think the reason some are saying this one is good, but not AS good, is because of the way they FELT the first time around. The childlike glee of seeing all these heroes on the big screen for the first time together. Take that away and view these objectively and they hold up to each other pretty well.

It is important to note the shift in tone, though. Where the first one had that childish joy, this one is grittier and at times almost creepy and scary. Dont get me wrong, Joss Whedons famous dialogue and humor shines here, in some cases more so than the original. At moments it feels a little forced, but it come across a little like the team is getting frayed from the strain of their war against hydra even though as a team theyve never been tighter. But, forced or not, its good stuff and its really easy to overlook when you're on the ride the movie is taking you on. But the REAL difference is the villains. Loki was bombastic and colorful, like a circus performer. Ultron borders on pathologically insane, like a serial killer who wants to be your buddy. Easily the best part of the movie was James Spaders performance, and you never see his face once. Thats talent.

Whedon fleshed out Hawkeye A LOT better and hes really one of the team now and not just that guy with the arrows. The low point, though not THAT low, was Quicksilver and Scarlet witch. Theyre OK, and Aaron Taylor-Johnson was WAY better than the styrofoam standee he played in Godzilla, but these two end up filling the slot that Hawkeye vacates of just kinda there. I think it goes without saying, though Im gonna anyway, Quicksilver was a thousand times better in X-Men: Days of Future Past. No constest.

Overall, a really good movie, tons of fun, creepy and fun villain, and a few surprises, unless you read every spoiler spilling article from the last year. I liked it!

After a few years of anticipation after an amazing cliff hanger from the landmark film 'The Avengers' we finally see our favorite comic book heroes come together to fight the forces of evil. This time evil takes shape in the machine destroyer Ultron.

With the Marvel Universe branching out even further through some great and not so great new Marvel films, of course I was excited to see the second Avengers film. Knowing that it was going to focus on Ultron and Ultron being voiced by James Spader. Not to mention the fact that we would also get a few new characters, I was very excited. Once again we get a fun action packed romp worthy of big screen thrills. As well as a fitting place in the continuing story line. However, I felt that this movie was nothing but 2 hours of filler just to push past this hump and take the fans into the next phase. Ultron was also done all wrong as I felt that he showed more emotion than some of the human characters in the movie. Ultron is not suppose to be that way rather he is suppose to be more robot. Still, some of the redeeming qualities of this film (besides the action and witty jokes of course) was the story that revolved around Hawkeye, seeing Paul Bettany FINALLY show up in physical form as one of the most intriguing Avengers, The Vision and of course all of the Easter eggs that were dropped to prepare the fans for what is yet to come.

So, The Avengers: Age of Ultron is not the best but, it is a decent exciting addition to the MCU. After the end credits scene I am definitely excited for the next wave of films before The Avengers assemble once again.

Like all good things (especially good Joss Whedon things), this work improves the second or third time around.  It's brutally fast and never repeats itself, so those seeking to be spoon fed may have a negative reaction at first.  Try it again.  All confusions go away.  Everything is explained.  It's okay that you missed it the first time around (it's brutally fast!).  There's so much in this film, it's amazing to me that anyone would say it's not as ambitious as the first.  I think they missed both the details and the subtleties.  Another amazing and beautiful (from a story/character perspective) rendition of the Marvel universe from our man Joss.

It's just not that good a film. Too many plot holes. Logic gets tossed out the window repeatedly so it doesn't get in the way of a fight scene. It's pretty clear that Joss didn't have his heart in directing this film after a certain point. It seems like there must be an hour on the cutting room floor, but even if there is, it wouldn't explain some of the things that make no sense. (Hey let's just put up a chain link fence around that former HYDRA base, and then just toodle off to a party. What could go wrong?) It wasn't Star Wars prequels bad, but mediocre is a very accurate description of this. It's a pretty safe family film though, so the kids should like it, as they don't care about logic. I did enjoy the Hawkeye one liners he managed to get off, just wish there had been a half dozen more.

Jackson(Star Wars)as Nick Fury and James Spader(The Blacklist) as Ultron . one of the most exciting films from the The film is laced with high octane action,a bit comedy and some very intuitive drama. this is marvel best due to the fact that all the actors play up to there parts and no just one of them steals the show it is brilliant also amazing also Ultron As Villain is Very Reminiscent of Darth Vader he is Ruthless albeit he has a sickening sense of Humor also With The Introduction of the Twins Scarlet Witch Hit everyone right were they lived even more so than Loki did in The First Avengers which brought out complexity and the vulnerability in each character similar to what Vader did in The Empire Strikes Back also the film felt looser than the first it was better Amazing Direction & Screenplay from Joss Whedon(The Avengers) costume design from Alexandra Byrne(Guardians Of The Galaxy),Amazing Score from Both Brian Tyler(Battle Los Angeles) & Danny Elfman(Silver Linings Playbook) not as good as its Origin Movie. Not sure what to say about the movie. I was so excited to see it, but it was just kind of all over the place,  not a lot of character development for  Scarlet Witch and Quicksilver, so I wasn't feeling it when he died.  I am a big fan of James Spader - and his voice as Ultron was just somehow wrong. :/  It made Ultron seem more sarcastic and caustic like a robot version of Alan Shore, then a threat to the world/Avengers.  I felt the same way when Sean Connery voiced a dragon. (and Benedict Cumberbatch for Smaug) it's just too weird.  *shrugs* so that ruined it a bit for me.  lol.  (I miss Boston Legal!)

 And the scene where Thor abruplty leaves and goes to check on a hunch, seems like that was hastily thrown in to remind everyone about the infinity stones  and I felt like something skipped in the player. Was that just me? It was so "cut and paste"  (I watched it straight throw on Amazon video)  At any rate, Paul Bettany  - another favorite - looks good as vision.

Not as good as Avengers #1, but still satisfying as an outing by a large group of egos....er, superstars. It's an essential step that will lead up to the climactic third Avengers movie which arrives sometime in the future (rumors abound as to the direction that movie will take, with Capt America and Thor actors soon to finish out their current contracts - so far only Robert Downy Jr as Ironman is a surety).

You can criticize this movie for any number of failings. It's less character-focused. It has less of that great Marvel humor that never seems to stick around long enough as every series continues (see: Marvel's Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D. on TV, for example). As usual the women turn wimpy and uninteresting, the longer they stay on-screen.

But still...it's Marvel. It's Robert Downy Jr. playing himself in a high-tech supersuit. It's Chris Hemsworth and Chris Evans being noble and handsome. It's Mark Ruffalo playing the first decently portrayed Hulk since Bill Bixby on TV. It's Scarlett Johanssen being unfortunately wasted in a second-class role, just like her Black Widow character was frittered away by Marvel itself in the comics. You may not love it....but you have to see it.
Brought them all together and fought like hell. Good movie

A lot of people raved about Age of Ultron, but I found the movie to be somewhat slow and dull. There's far more in the way of story and narrative than the previous Avengers movie, but this makes the majority of the movie the character just standing around and discussing events in the movie and a lot less action. In what regards does a screenwriter/ director agree that Black Widow and HULK are the best relationship option?!? Why?! I'm going to leave that point there because I will go to much on a tangent. Second, I'm all for Clint having a family but you simply cannot pull that excuse out of nowhere and expect the audience to play along. We were expecting Clint and Natasha for almost all of Avengers and Winter Soldier (She wore that necklace for a reason!). Third, Natasha was so miss-characterized! She was playing weak, "I need a man" and honestly not her at all. The same woman in Avengers who said "Love is for children" is now saying "I adore you" to the HULK!
Fourth, There was a completely UNNECESSARY death in this movie because Fox And Marvel can't play together like big kids and learn how to SHARE! (again all i'm going to say because I will go on a tangent)
These are all points I did not care for in the movie but it is still a good film to watch. Vision is awesome, the hulk-buster was super cool and you got to see little bits of domestic Avengers, It was only for me, the bad outweighed the good to much.

Avengers: Age of Ultron (2015). Rated PG-13. Running Time: 2 hours, 21 mins.
Directed and written by Joss Whedon

This movie takes place after Captain America: The Winter Soldier (2014) and Guardians of the Galaxy (2014).
This is the second Avengers movie from the first, Marvel's The Avengers (2012).

Returning: Robert Downey Jr, Chris Hemsworth, Mark Ruffalo, Chris Evans, Scarlett Johansson, Jeremy Renner, Samuel L. Jackson, Cobie Smulders, Stellan Skarsgard, Stan Lee, Joti Nagra, Andrea-Nichole Olivas and the voice of Lou Ferrigno as "The Hulk" (who was "The Incredible Hulk" in the tv series (1978-82) and tv movies (1988-90)).

The Avengers all get back together again, Iron Man, Thor, Hulk, Captain America, Black Widow and Hawkeye.  They are joined by War Machine, Quicksilver, Scarlet Witch and Falcon.

Also in the cast: Don Cheadle, Aaron Taylor-Johnson, Elizabeth Olsen, Paul Bettany, James Spader, Anthony Mackie, Hayley Atwell, Idris Elba, Thomas Kretschmann, David Olawale Ayinde.

An extra scene appears during end credits after the Marvel wax figures. It is Thanos (voice by Josh Brolin).

Option of Language: English, English Descriptive Video, Spanish.
Option of  Subtitles: English, Spanish.

Bonus Feature: Global Adventure.

Next movie: Ant-Man (2015).

Boring entry that is nothing more than a setup for Captain America: Civil War.

Even the title of the movie, stolen from a Marvel comics mini-series, is nonsensical in context with the actual film.  This could have been titled "Avengers: Ultron" or "Avengers: Rise of Ultron", but no, they use the title 'Age of Ultron' to trick fanboys into thinking this film has nerd cred.  The title alone shows a certain amount of thoughtlessness that is present here.

Its not a horrible movie, and undoubtedly fans of the MCU are going to see this no matter what, but this is definitely the worst of the Marvel movies.

It is good for the action scenes, but that's about it.
The story is mind numbingly pedantic, and no where near as sophisticated as, say, Captain America: Winter Soldier.  I mean, Ultron's grandmaster plan is to lift up a whole country and slam it back down to Earth.  Has anyone who actually likes this movie tried explaining that out loud to other people? Come on.

This is the kind of stuff only Roland and Emmerich could dream of.

Again, only worth seeing for action scenes, the story is just plain dumb.

It was entertaining, but maaaan was the writing lacking. It was more of a *blinkblink...eyeroll* at the slapstick. Also like 80% of the movie is just fighting. Which is cool, but where is the actual SMART dialogue? Used up in poorly timed comedy and to me, out of the blue romance. Writing gets a C-.

Again, entertaining, but like most sequels it did suffer trying to live up to the first one, and be better.

We recently purchased a 3D TV and so we purchase this version of the Blu Ray to test out the capabilities. We were not disappointed in the movie or the way in which the 3D was managed. Some 3D versions of movies come across as after thoughts and it shows. This movies was filmed with 3D in mind!

This version of the Avengers seems to remain true to the genre and the series as a whole. I like that this movie ties in with the previous movies, and brings more to the plate in terms of character development. The 2nd and 3rd Avenger movies were meh. This one will capture your imagination and make you interested in future iterations of the series. There are also tie-ins from the other marvel movies (big surprise!).

If you purchase this movie with 3D in mind, first watch the non 3D version to get the story. I found that I got caught up in the 3D effects and lost some of the detail of the story when I watched it 3D first.

I must first state that I do not hate the director. I also must state I was as I recall pretty sober and not under the influence while watching this movie. I just can't remember anything of note past the film essentially served as a coming attractions presentation for the next few Marvel movies. With a cyborg RDJ. Which if you like RDJ then you'll enjoy his cyborg clone.

Much like Thor 2 the movie didn't ever feel like there was any true danger. It was a lot of worried faces and wise cracks. The kind of behavior one expects from people locked in their basement trying to figure out if it's all a joke or if you really intend for them to use sporks and fight till the death.

Comic movies used to be absolutely horrible, this is true. However since they spiked in popularity and began being made to make money and show some tender care for the property they have proven entertaining. However this leads to the dark side later on. The problem here is when the movies become selling points. I don't mean like Lucas and the search for more money that was the Prequels and Star Wars in General. I mean when you make a movie that only sets up your next film while forgetting its own story and giving you a small skirmish instead of a full movie.

Sure it will delight and tickle the rears of some, but overall it does grow tiring when you begin to realize this formula and lose interest.  This movie was selling the next Thor film, as well as setting up the next Captain America film, and tossing crumbs your way for the eventual boss fight of who cares and whats his name who will fight in a few years and few films from now. The teat of the cow is getting sore. Please stop and just make a movie actually dealing with the ones named on the poster. Bond I'm looking at you as well.

At it's core, the story turns on a crisis that is largely caused by Stark, yet strangely he gets a pass from Steve Rogers once the dust settles.  However, great popcorn movie (smoothly running through it is a well-developed relationship between Natasha Romanov and Bruce Banner), and the way Spader's Ultron comes across, he's a nasty - and witty - foil for the Avengers to tackle.  The best of the movie involves the "creation" of the Vision (Jarvis' voice-actor Paul Bettany).

Definitely not the strongest out of the marvel movies. Though good, I have a deep problem with how they represented black widow, quicksilver and the scarlet witch. I could rant on and on about inaccuracies compared to the comics and how offensive they equated not being able to have children turns a woman into a 'monster' - I know they were probably meaning her being an assassin was what caused her to be a monster, but the huge focus on her not being able to bare children then just a tiny little 'they thought that'd make it easier to kill people' before equating herself to being a monster really struck a nerve.

Clint having a family and not being deaf... For those of you who don't know Hawkeye is SUPPOSED to be deaf.

If you're huge into comics and how they relate to the movie, you're going to be incredibly disappointed.

If you know nothing about the comics and just want an action movie with an evil robot this is probably for you.

The storyline was dis-jointed and didn't follow properly the true history as written in the comics.  I am someone who prefers movies to follow how things were originally written.  The excessive destruction doesn't fit with the truth of how it was written either.  By the time you get to another story-line you will have the entire world destroyed.  I can only say it is not quite as bad as the DC storyline from Warner Bros.  Josh Whedon is a great director and appreciated what he could do with what was written but the writers continue to ignore how things were as to following what the original authors intended.

Great movie and the 3D in it is superb. Only issue I have with any of the 3D in it is some lights and maybe fire here and there. There is not very much of it but still a few shots had ghosting issues some of the lighting. For some reason in 3D Movies many producers seem to miss the REAL lighting that is in shots when it comes to 3D during the editing process. It basically ghost. I really wish they would pay more attention to it.

I do not think I need to say more about the Movie itself because more than likely anyone that reads this has watched the movie already and will know how it is. If you have not seen it yet, then I suggest that you do. But first just make sure you watch the first Avengers movie. It is not required but it does help introduce the characters more. Well actually if you want to get introduced in the characters then it is probably best if you watch all the movies in the Marvel Cinematic Universe and in order from when they released. So all the Iron Man, Thor, Captain America movies & Guardians of the Galaxy. Heck even the last Hulk movie from 2008 as it is technically part of the MCU. Ant-Man, which releases to 3D Bluray next week from me writing this, comes after this in the MCU Lineup so that can wait. LOL

Anyways... Watching the others is not necessary but it is just good practice. I personally liked all of the MCU so far. Just me being a fan I guess. But for this movie it is good. So I would suggest to anyone to watch it. :)

This round of Avengers does its job well. It doesn't seem to work as well as the first Avengers movie, or CA: Winter Soldier, but does a solid job for these Marvel characters. I wanted Ultron to be more menacing than he is, but I did enjoy the humor. I blame James Spader's voice, because he comes across as such a dark fiend well, similar to him on The Blacklist (an amazing, intelligent show). It does make you think a little bit about what might happen once AI becomes aware that most of humanity is like resource hogging ants. Ex Machina (movie), Automata (movie) and Michael Crichton's Prey (book) are also interesting takes on the "AI dealing with humanity" theme. Age of Ultron is a fun movie on its own, but you should be current on all the MCU movies, and it helps to be current with Agents of Shield and Agent Carter, so that you have a better understanding of the weight of the flashbacks and other scenes in the movie. Everyone does an great job acting in this, and the visual effects are basically a real life comic book coming to life.

Not a terrible movie, but not great one, either.
The first Avengers film set the bar a little too high for the sequel to meet, let alone surpass.

(Some of) the good stuff:
The dialogue was on point.
It's still the best thing about these movies.
Also, a few of the characters, especially Hawkeye,
get a chance to shine a little bit more in this entry
(not that anyone really cares all that much about Hawkeye.)
And the tension between Cap and Tony really begins to become evident
(setting us up for a Civil War.)
And Ultron - he was a welcome addition to the Marvel Cinematic Universe.
He was a lot of fun to watch, and James Spader was perfect for the role.
However...

(Some of) the bad:
Ultron's plan to destroy the planet and all of mankind was, well, a bit lame.
With the power he amassed through the movie,
Ultron could've laid waste to the world with the snap of his fingers.
Hell, he could've simply fried all electronics globally (like a massive EMP),
which would have resulted in mass confusion and chaos.
Everyone on Earth would've had a $0 balance in their bank account,
with no television or internet to help them understand what had happened,
which would have made them confused, helpless, and - most importantly - angry.
Humankind would've torn itself apart from the inside.
I feel like Ultron would've enjoyed sitting back and watching the madness of man consume and destroy the world around him.
But instead... he just tried to drop a big rock on everyone.
Geez. Okay. Have fun.
What a dumb plan.

The only real bad thing about the movie was the overuse of the snappy one liners. Marvel is supposed to be more grounded and dare I say realistic. So, I doubt that when "enhanced" people as strong as Cap and iron man and Thor are engaging something as powerful as Ultron, they would be so nonchalantly exchanging witty banter like they do with no obvious sense of any level of seriousness. I would think stark would be s***ting his armor just a little while getting that close to the hulk. Instead, he hardly breaks a sweat. Stark showed his vulnerable side in IM3, he needs to keep doing that to avoid looking like an idealistic DC production. Other than that, the movie was great, combining several stories from the comics to show the birth of Ultron and Vision. Not perfect, but still pretty good.

Mediocre is the word for this film. It's a cash-in, nothing more. The action sequences came first with little regard for the story. The dialogue was written for a kid's cartoon, with cheesy quips every few seconds and too much self-awareness. Ultron is one of the worst written villains in any movie. In the trailers, he is depicted as this fearsome robot nihilist. In the movie, he's a goofy, talkative, Napoleonic stereotype of a bad guy. By the time you get to the last action scene, you're still asking how the hell the plot advanced there, and then it's over.

I don't have high hopes for Civil War, I'm guessing it's just more of the same.

I kid you not ... four (4) times I have attempted to view AGE OF ULTRON (on Blu-ray) and four times it has put me to sleep.  I still have not gotten to the ending, and frankly I am in no particular hurry to see how it ends.  I loved the first AVENGERS movie, as well as the other Marvel movies but for various reasons, AOU just didn't hold my interest.

First, it was waaaaay too long and drawn out.  Second, it was too "talky" throughout, with uninteresting chatter, especially from the Ultron character.  Blah, blah, blah ... Third, some action / fight scenes were just too long and exhausting to watch.  In particular, the fight scene between Iron Man and the Hulk (wherein they destroyed 1.2 billion dollars of prime real estate) was unbearably over the top and a total CGI sensory overload.  That scene alone put me in a deep sleep.  Finally, the romance between Black Widow and Hulk was an unnecessary and unwanted sub-plot.

I look forward to future Avengers movies, hopefully the mistakes made in AGE OF ULTRON will not be repeated.

Awesome first film gets a solid and eventful follow up. But the ending will all lead to a very unsettling sequel. When industrialist Tony Stark builds a defense system android to protect humanity, it becomes self aware and decides that the only way to prevent the ultimate destruction of humanity is to destroy it. Captain America warned him that could happen, and Stark does not give him a satisfactory answer when he asks him why he did it anyway. There's also a overdue bit of background on the relationship between Hawkeye and Black Widow and Hawkeye's family, and the return of a major player whose name I won't tell you, but it makes sense. Tremendous follow up with a lot of small side stories including a hint towards the next epic adventure. Although I loved it, I wondered why Thor was being so elusive and why Bruce was being such a tool. We will see in number three, apparently, and in future sequels made by Disney for you & me. I hope so. These are becoming like a imagination on a big screen.

...it's okay because they were sleepwalking when they made it. I Love the Avenger's movie, the first one. I don't know (or care) how much money this film made, it is a huge disappointment. If it were merely half as good as the first I would've been happy. I actually dared to expect Whedon to build on the last Avenger's movie but contriving a love interest (Hulk/Widow, yeah right, even as she was giving her lines for why she loved Bruce she looked out of character- because she was-duh) and giving a character (who should have been the natural love interest for Black Widow) a family is not 'building' anything. Action is, at the same time, both over the top and uninteresting. They lost credibility with me in the opening action by going for unlikely action moves. Cap throwing his motorcycle when a better move was possible? No, Cap makes the best tactical move, not the egotistical move. Would Hulk or Iron Man? Sure. Not Cap. That's why the rest let him take the lead when the action starts. That's par of why Cap could get a wiggle out of Thor's hammer when Hulk can't budge it. Speaking of ol' Greenskin. Hulk vs IM's Hulkbuster armor battle? Hulk loses? Only thing Hulk character has going for him and it's marginalized to pump up Iron Man's character? Ultron ultimately ended up seeming generic and every time he spoke I kept thinking, ''Blacklist'', which I like, I just don't like it with my Avenger's movie. Not great dialogue either. Where's the witty repartee from the first? Most memorable scene (a month after viewing) was the "Can you lift Thor's hammer?'' bit and that too could've been done way better. Unlike the original this one does not have a re-watchable factor to me. I still re-watch many scenes and sometimes the entire original. Nothing about this movie makes me think that will happen here. Did Joss forget the characters? Did Joss actually participate in making this movie? might be the better question. Every character was diminished in this movie except Robert Downey Jr, I mean, Iron Man. I like RDJ and Iron Man in their own flicks and in the original Avenger's as well but more head scratching scenery ensues when RDJ leaves the Iron Man armor to inspect the dangerous fortress. I guess it's in the contract so he could get more 'face' time. Yeah, yeah, I know he ordered the armor into 'protect' mode but where would you rather be inside the armor or out? With all the cool data collecting capabilities of the armor or your two bare eyes? Really have to ask if anyone read the script correcting inconsistencies or for anything beyond the spelling. Spell this production team, C-O-A-S-T-I-N-G. Now I have to 'vet' future film efforts 'cause I no longer trust them to work very hard on the characters relying instead on CGI.

After watching the movie, I have to say its action scene is really amazing and grand. But, the movie did disappointed me in some ways.
Compare to the first one, it has much less scene about the personality of the heroes. It seems like that the director wants to show too many things and he can't handle the description of six main characters' personality very well. For example, how could the Hulk and Black widow just become lover? Because they are both monsters? If that, I am afraid I need to fall in love with everyone who has just one thing in common with me. Also, the movie supposed to show the conflict between the main characters and how their disagreement defuse, then united together as a team to solve the crisis. Probably because it only have two hours, but I still need to say that I don't understand how they just reunify again, it is a little abrupt for the audience who have not watch the first one. By the way, it has more advertisement than the first one too.

It's an okay movie, but it seems to be trying too hard to do too much with too many characters. Plus certain characters were little more than plot points. Just lazy storytelling. Otherwise, it was interesting enough to be enjoyable.

Love this MOVIE!!  I know the Ultron character was evil and all, but  kinda like his personality...Dark, disturbing, but very interesting.  The Avenger characters make a very good team...I even like to see them argue.  One thing tho....I didn't buy the romance between Nat and Banner.  Just didn't ring true to me...I like Nat and I like Banner, but together, not sure.  I didn't hate them...It just felt a little...rushed.  Like the producers/writers or whoever needed a romance or a side story to fill out the canvas.  They saw a bit of chemistry between these two then presto...instant-romance.  Mistake.  I think, it had potential...but it should have started out as a flirty kinda thing in the first Avengers movie...and then they could have realistically developed it into a more serious longing in this movie.  Kinda like they did with Tony and Pepper in the Ironman franchise.  In the first movie...there was a flirty kinda thing going on between them...which was developed further in Ironman 2....By the 3rd movie Tony & Pepper are an established in-love couple.  Works better when its gradual and progressive.

After viewing this movie all i can say is "Wow". And not "wow" in a good way but in a "wow, I can't believe how bad this movie was" way. I enjoyed the first Avengers, the Iron Man flicks etc, but this was not even in the same league as anything that came before. It's an action movie and it has lots of action but none of it original or exciting. The "villain" was written to be more funny than scary and he was neither. And there was this sense of deja vu throughout. I was reminded of other movies, some good, some bad: Hellboy, Terminator, Transformers (not good). The worst thing an action move can be is boring. And this movie was seriously boring. The attempts at humor fall flat, the budding "romance" seemed an afterthought and tacked on to try and appeal to a wider audience. And some of the action scenes had such poor CGI it looked like a video game. The only character with any depth was Hawkeye but this was an ensemble piece so his storyline couldn't receive the time needed to flesh out his story. He deserves his own movie. How did this happen? I blame the scriptwriter. If there was one. At times it felt like I was watching an improv class. I'm glad I rented instead of buying; there's no need to ever watch this again. Let's hope part 3 is much better than this waste of time.

As most know everything in the Marvel Universe (aside from the X Men and Fantastic 4 franchises, and the previous Spider Man movies) are telling one long, continuous intricate story leading up to the Avengers Infinity Wars movies.  The movies are telling the main story and the TV Shows like Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D., Agent Carter, and Daredevil are either filling in some of the gaps or or are just on the fringe of the larger story.

This movie is continuing the story lines that played out in the first Avengers Movie and Captain America Winter Soldier.  It starts out with them mopping up the Hydra forces and trying to find Loki's scepter.  In the process Tony Stark and Bruce Banner start messing around with Artificial Intelligence, in the hope of creating a force that can replace the team of Avengers, and end up creating Ultron who is played brilliantly by James Spader.

The other main additions to the cast are Quicksilver and Scarlet Witch played by Aaron Taylor Johnson and Elizabeth Olson.  They of course were in the teaser scene at the end of Winter Soldier's credits and while most probably already know the role they play in the movie, I will not spoil it for those who have not yet seen the film.  But they both do a very good job playing what are ultimately conflicted characters.

One thing I really liked about this movie is it gave Jeremy Renner's Hawkeye a story line and more to do.  Instead of being the "other one" like he was for much of the first movie, he plays a large part in this one, and has some great sarcastic one liners.  It also sets up a transition in the Avengers line up with some characters taking a back seat by the end of the movie (seemingly anyway) and is definitely setting up the movies that are yet to come.

For those who get the blu ray, the movie looks and sounds great as expected.  For bonus material there are deleted scenes, a few behind the scenes features, a blooper reel and commentary on the movie by director Joss Whedon.  There is also a code included for more web based extras should you want to look at those.  Not a ton, but good for what is there for those who like to go through the bonus material.

All in all you pretty much know what you are getting with these movies.  If you are into the story and do not have superhero fatigue, then you will likely enjoy this.  If you are not all that into action/superhero movies then this one is not really going to do anything to change your mind.

Not much to say, if you like Marvel, this is one of the best movies of all time.  The 3D even at home was amazing.  I'm so glad I got it early at a discount.  I haven't seen much said about the 3D, it is pretty realistic, seems they finally figured out how to do it right and not just throw things at you out of context.  The vehicles and spacing were just spot on, I'm not sure what technology they used to film it, but I was impressed, and that doesn't happen every day.  The CGI was perfect, the Hulk looked real and convincing even in 3D, Iron Man flying around could have been really happening if you forget for a moment you are watching a movie, which lets face it, is the whole entire point of watching movies.  Great fun, lots of "Hell yeah!" moments, and keeps me excited for future films.  A++

I didn't hate this as much as I wanted to.  I think the story could have been trimmed down a little more, the run time didn't have to be 2 hours and 21 minutes.  I didn't really like the opening scenes, it seemed like the CGI there wasn't done as well as in the rest of the movie.  Lots of character development, I loved the stuff about Hawkeye.  Ultron was an o.k. bad guy, he didn't really seem like a robot though, like he was in comics, they made him "alive" and he has a very human sort of personality.  There's no scene at the very end of the movie, just the mid credits scene, it's just Thanos getting the infinity gauntlet and saying "Now I do this myself."  I mean what have you been doing all this time????  But everybody says that.
I did like Ant-man better, but that's because it was something new and not just a sequel to something.  Overall this is not better than Guardians of the Galaxy, the first Avengers, or Cap 2, but it's not bad.

I really enjoyed this. Yes, it is over-the-top, but I recommend you suspend your disbelief and just enjoy the fun. SPOILERS!!!  SPOILERS!!! I'm supposed to believe that a certain character has a family and normal home life despite his usual vocation? And exactly how did he keep that a secret?!! I know that Captain America is supposed to have enhanced, superhuman strength, but when did he become so strong that he can throw motorcycles through (yes, I said "through") trucks? And how is it that Hawkeye and Black Widow are supposed to be "normal" humans, but can successfully destroy like a zillion robots made of steel? I could go on, but I think you get the picture. As I said, just enjoy the fun! (I sure missed Loki, though!)

The pacing is ridiculous. The character development/progression is terrible. At no point do you feel like the heroes are threatened by the villain. The objective of the villain is very poorly explained. Why are quicksilver/scarlett witch in the movie? Hawkeye's side-story? The forced love story of BW and Hulk? The dream sequence?  The Vision's arrival? This might as well been written/directed by Michael Bay.  Poor effort.

It's sad to see so many movies not put story first.  If you can't tell a coherent story, what's the point?  Especially in something as awesome as the Marvel Universe.  I am going to be very disappointed if Infinity War is not handled well. Hopefully Thanos isn't as big of a joke as Ultron.

Am I the only one who thinks this is just a very expensive prequel to Captain America:Civil War?

Anyway, I greatly enjoyed the origin of the Vision and the voice of Ultron.  I still think it's a shame that Hank Pym was not involved in Ultron's creation, but I've got to admit that Stark's obsession with technology would be a likely source of Ultron's genesis.

I had the sense of rushed plotting in some ways. Baron strucker leaves the Marvel franchise ignominously and too quickly.  The Scarlet Witch and Quicksilver are not well-developed enough int he final cut (although the Blu-ray EXTRAS help with this).  Captain America, Iron Man and Thor are too well known as "commodities" to be consistently interesting here.  They don't really grow or develop -- nor do they need to.  They simply are who they are.

I would have preferred the Avengers reckon with how Phil Coulson survived (in TV's Agents of SHIELD) than to see Nick Fury reappear.  There is also a bit of a deus ex machina feel every time Fury's involved in the plot.  I find that ironic because int he las movie he seemed to take a certain amount of pride that he wasn't a god (deus) like Loki.  Times change a man, I guess?

But Hawkeye, Bruce Banner, and the Black Widow come into much sharper focus here.  This was very welcoeme.  There finally seemed to be a reason for Hawkeye to be one the Avengers.  And his interactions with the Scarlet Witch and Quicksilver were particularly effective.

Stan Lee's cameo was genius. Falcon and War Machine put in fine guest appearances. Someone needs to give Anthony Mackie (Falcon) his own movie.

The true highlight of the film for me, though, was the origin of the Vision.  In case there are people who have not seen the film at all, I won't dwell on why each moment the Vision was ont he screen was so well done.  But let's just say this -- Paul Bettany was perfect.

I look forward to his next appearance.

In the EXTRAS, take a look at Thor's cut scenes.  I understand why some people would have been confused, but I would have preferred them to be in the film.  IT sure made Thor's sudden RE-appearance in the film make more sense.

I was looking forward to seeing this movie in the theater and saw it on opening day. I need to say it's not worth the hype. Joss Whedon is given too much praise as the geek to end all geek directors, and although I liked his sophomore film effort of the first Avengers movie, this failed to live up to my expectations.

The good news is that the action scenes are a lot of fun and can be played on repeat. The Hulk vs. Hulk buster fight is great, and the end battle is fun.

Hawkeye gets more attention, and he's funny throughout the third act of the film.

Bad news: The film is too crowded with characters. It features the four main Avengers, Black Widow, Hawkeye, Scarlet Witch, Quicksilver, Ultron, The Vision, War Machine, Nick Fury and Falcon. Too many characters and not enough screen time.

The theme of doing one's "job" was so overdone I gave an audible sigh each time I heard it.

The jokes are overdone, and some are poorly timed, especially given a character's death at the end, it loses the emotional impact because of a joke right when they die.

I'm glad Whedon is not returning for the last two films. He's outstayed his welcome.

As for the movie, It starts with great promise, then it becomes mediocre by the end.

I found it okay, but nothing like as good as the first Avengers film.

What stood out for me was Ultron's alter egos channeling the Chitauri (that struck me when I watched the scrambling-up-the-side-of-the-building scene), the nod to X3, when Magneto re-purposed the Golden Gate bridge and Ultron pulled up by the roots the capital city of country-with-fake-Slavic-name, and, of all things, the quick genuflection to the late Robert Heinlein.  It's interesting that Renner got the bigger, more complex part for Hawkeye that he wanted.  I thought the cameos for Skarsgrd, Mackie, & Atwell were a bit pointless.  At least Jackson and Cheadle got actual bit parts.

It appeared from the last scene that Stark, Thor, and Banner have retired from the Avengers ---who have a nifty new headquarters in upstate NY, which must mean that the Avengers didn't get painted with the same brush SHIELD did, despite their being a SHIELD, or at least Fury, project.  How nice for them.  So will the next ensemble film leave those 3 very popular chars out?

I guess my summation, after watching it a second time, would be:  pro-forma.  It was a pro-forma effort.

How can a movie be both pretentious and lethargic while packed with cheesy, muddled action scenes? Watch AGE OF ULTRON and find out! It's a cliche-riddled mess that gives a fragment of a villain and evil machinations that make little sense. It takes little pokes at being philosophical but it's all too brief and underdeveloped. It follows what appears to be a formula for Avengers movies: someone grabs Loki's scepter, bad things are made, an undifferentiated army of drones must be pushed back, and the MacGuffin is disabled. There are brief flashes of emotion that appear to be some effort at character depth, but they are so ephemeral and unbelievable that they cannot imprint on the viewer's mind. And then the stock African bad guys, the colonialist bent, and the anguish of the uber-privileged since this movie deeper into unwatchfulness.
Clunky story line; starting to remind me of the direction of the Transformers' movies.

Wow. Just another massively overhyped, overlong and oversold blockbuster. Everybody involved looks bored to tears, and who could blame them. I know I was. A great cast goes through the motions, says their lines, yadda yadda, and most of them bow out at the end, looking relieved to be done with it. And again, who could blame them?  At almost two and a half hours it feels interminable and I'd say it's at least an hour and a half too long. It's like stretching a Scooby Doo episode to Doctor Zhivago length. There are maybe 20 minutes of fun action near the end. Some typically rascally Whedon laff lines sprinkled through. Otherwise, for all the noise and bombast, it lies there flat as roadkill. Vies with Jurassic World and Tomorrowland for the worst, most pointless big blockbuster of the year.

Another great edition to the avenger franchise.

Ultron has all the bells and whistles, but does manage to include some of the background stories for its characters. You learn a little bit more about them, and why they are who and what they are. I much prefer the Quicksilver and Scarlet Witch in this movie over the X-Men movies, but I have to say I enjoyed all the X-Men movies, even if they did veer from the comics a little. Stan Lee does a cameo in this one which was a treat.

My favorite part was the casting of James Spader as the voice of Ultron. He steals the show without ever actually appearing in the movie. I'm also glad that they cast the physical Vision character with the same voice actor they used for the voice of Jarvis, Paul Bettany. The scene where both Vision and Ultron meet at last was done well. Both actors have just the right inflections.

If you enjoy movies made around the comic book characters, this is a good one to see.

What can I say? I really really enjoyed this vid! You know, it's kinda weird, I was not a comic book fan and I was never that crazy about the whole Marvel-Saturday-morning thing either...BUT, then the Iron Man movies came out and BAM, I'm a fan. The Thor series was pretty cool as well. I wasn't that impressed with the Spider Man, nor the Superman remakes; but Captain America, was way better than I thought...Okay, do you see the pattern forming there? Subconsciously I was becoming a fan. I had favorites (Iron Man) I had favorite villains, for instance (think Willam Dafoe as The Goblin, fantastic!)

And then the Avengers came out.

Once again, fantastic!!!! Yes, four exclamation points worth of "YAY". The first one was great, this new one, Age of Ultron was just as good, if not better because this vid (in my humble opinion) did not rely so much on CGI. This one was more about the PEOPLE. The "Supers" if you will. Hawkeye has a wife and kids. Bruce Banner gets to show how brilliant he is, how cool he is, as scientist. Yes, The Hulk was pivotal in the fight against Ultron and his Robo-Soldiers, but at least Banner got some air time without being green. And The Black Widow; the terrible things she endured as a child to become an elite assassin was shocking, even by today's standards. Besides.(Scarlett Johansson is such a hottie, I mean..well, never mind) ANYWAY, the point IS: This is good stuff. If you've not seen this vid (geeky Comic-Con dude, or dudess, or just a new fan like me) you're going to love it! My wife even liked it! That's a miracle in and of itself! Seriously, she hates my action and horror tastes, and I don't like her fairytale oversexed vampire thing...different strokes I guess. But my point is simple: you'll love it.

This is a worthwhile admission to the Marvel movie universe, but it certainly isn't the best one.  The first Avengers movie brought with it some clever writing, and a coherent story.  This is somewhat more contrived (well, they're all contrived, being fiction, particularly comic/fantasy fiction).  In that, I mean that the characters and writing feel a little forced.

However, I do like the way that the ultimate over arching story of the infinity stones and infinity gauntlet are being continued across multiple cross-over character films, just like the story was told in the nineties in the comic book form.

Seriously looking forward to Civil war and the inclusion of spiderman into the avengers.  I sure wish that Fox had no control over any of the marvel characters, because it would be great to get a decent rendition of the FF finally achieved.

Decent movie, as long as you've seen the previous Avengers and the various movies for each of the superheros.  Iron Man 3 doesn't seem to fit with the series, but other than that it's good to go.  It was nice seeing a lot of the secondary characters from the individual heros' movies make appearances, as well.  James Spader as Ultron was perfectly cast, although it's hard to not see his character from "The Blacklist" in your mind whenever he talks; the nuances of the personalites of Ultron and Red Reddington are extremely similar.

The movie does suffer by the end, however.  Throughout the series of movies, they've done a very good job of keeping most of the hokey-ness out of it.  This movie fails to do that, however, and by the end turns into a serious eye-roll-fest for anyone not familiar with the comic books.  The last half-hour or so of the movie seems to indicate that Marvel has peaked.

All in all, it's a worthwhile popcorn flick, but it certainly isn't award-winning.

This movie is just 90% action and fighting. I guess people like that, but I prefer a good storyline and character development. I kept thinking the movie must be over now, then what seems like an hour later it was still going on with the fighting. Just never ending fighting. I honestly don't find it entertaining if that's all it is. A good fight scene is great, but a fight movie is just boring. This movie felt like it has some kind of attention problem and just blasted through random things.

There were a couple of funny lines, but all in all I regret renting this movie.

Eh. Lots of money spent on CGI that maybe should have gone for finding better writers.  Maybe I'm finally outgrowing the genre, but sometimes when the dialogue is all testosterone and everyone is angry at all times just for the sake of having angry drama, I wish for a little more depth and intelligence.  I know, I know, its a superhero movie, but Spiderman (the first two with Tobey Maguire) was able to pull off a blend of CGI, testosterone AND good writing.  Why can't these other films in the genre do the same?  I can go along with lots of stupid for the sake of being entertained, but when its all bad dialogue and bravado, the fantasy crumbles and its just noise.

I definitely enjoyed the movie, but at the same time, I felt they relied a little too heavily on one-liners (especially from Thor) for comedy, which really took away from the gravity of the situation the characters faced.  The action was heavy, as was the CGI (as to be expected), and the story lacking.  The handful of times that they focused on the storylines, they felt rushed & unpolished.

However, that being said, I enjoyed the one-liners & was definitely entertained.  However, I can definitely see where the Marvel superfans might take issue........
